books.title: In the Court's Hands
books.author: Gartland, Fiona
books.notes: As she’s enjoying her lunch in the park, court reporter Bea Barrington witnesses an exchange between the main suspect in a case she’s been working on and a mysterious woman. Is the accused trying to tamper with the jury assigned to his case, or is there something more sinister going on?[return][return]This well-written novel follows Bea as she solves the mystery that she stumbled upon, forcing her to revisit her own personal history in the process. I enjoyed reading this book, mixing classic crime fiction tropes with unsual characters and some unexpected plot twists. I liked Bea’s character and I hope that we will get to read more about her adventures.

books.title: The Bathwater Conspiracy
books.author: Kellough, Janet
books.notes: After a virus wiped down the Earth's entire male population, society has rearranged and life goes on in a new matriarchal, if somewhat dystopic, world. One day, detective Carson “Mac” MacHenry is sent to rubber stamp the routine autopsy of a murdered university student. But the violence of the crime and the obvious desire of the "Darmes" state police to bury the case set off all of Mac's alarm bells and she decides to investigate...[return][return]This novel mixes classic post-apocalyptic tropes with original elements, and builds a quite convincing world. I enjoyed the main character's personality and found the story well built and enjoyable, although a bit predictable. I received an advance copy of this novel through the Early Reviewers program.

books.title: Murder in a Very Small Town
books.author: Jolley, Greg
books.notes: Wiki Danser is on her way to her family cottage in Michigan when a snow storms strands her in an unknown small town, running over the town sheriff in the process. As she stumbles out of her wrecked car into the worsening storm, the town loses power and rifle shots start echoing...[return][return]I found this story entertaining, although not very well written. The characters and situations are not very realistic: who drives through a snow storm in a sundress? Who takes so many hot showers while someone is shooting up the whole town? The story stumbles along, cutting from a scene to the next without much continuity, as if there were pages missing. Mercifully, it's short enough not to be too annoying. I feel the premise is interesting but not very well realized, and more careful editing could have fixed the most glaring flaws.

books.title: Feta and the Fat Bastard (Whine & Cheese Cozy Mystery Series Book 3)
books.author: Volhart, Judy
books.notes: Just as business is about to pick up in Amalia's bistro, a young woman drops dead within minutes of finishing her salad. When the rumors about the victim having been poisoned by the salad start spreading, Amalia must rush in to solve the mystery, clear her restaurant's reputation and save her business.[return][return]This is an amusing read, however the story is pretty contrived and peppered with too many unlikely characters for my taste. Also, I shudder at the idea of venturing inside a restaurant that only carries generic quirky named wines and uses a microwave to melt cheese for pasta toppings...

books.title: Smoke City
books.author: Rosson, Keith
books.notes: Marvin is old, much older than the life he's currently living, that of a 57 year old record store owner with a mysterious and seemingly endless supply of mint first editions. For this is not the only life he has lived. Ever since he lit the pyre that burned Joan of Arc in 1431, he keeps reincarnating, forced by the Curse into a eternity of miserable lives to atone for his sin. But this time, Marvin saw something he's never seen before: a woman on a TV reality show says she's a reincarnation of Joan of Arc. Convinced this is his way to seek the forgiveness he needs to end the Curse. As he sets off to travel to Los Angeles and meet her, Marvin meets two other drifters, each seeking their own version of forgiveness...[return][return]This is the second book by Keith Rosson that I've read, and I enjoyed it even more than the first one. This story takes a decidedly original take on reincarnation and atonement, and tells it through a hard to love but ultimately quite touching set of characters. A great read.

books.title: Innovation Nation: How Canadian Innovators Made the World Smarter, Smaller, Kinder, Safer, Healthier, Wealthier, Happier
books.author: Johnston, David
books.notes: This wonderful collection of Canadian inventions of all kinds (including many unexpected ones) is an excellent way to celebrate Canada's 150th anniversary. Lovingly illustrated, each invention is described with a short and engaging text that should appeal to anyone age 6 and up. We read it multiple times with my 7yo daughter and it gained a spot on her shelf of favourite books. A good gift idea!

books.title: The Coaching Habit: Say Less, Ask More & Change the Way You Lead Forever
books.author: Bungay Stanier, Michael

books.title: Saving Tarboo Creek: One Family’s Quest to Heal the Land
books.author: Freeman, Scott
books.notes: Intertwined with anecdotes about the author's family efforts to restore a stream on their property in the Pacific Northwest are reflections about ecology, humanity's impact on the land, global warming and those that try to take care of nature. It is not an overly optimistic book, the author stresses that new generations (starting with that of his own children) will live a dramatically different life unless the population as a whole undergoes drastic lifestyle changes. However, Freeman also highlights possible actions to mitigate ecological impact, by his own example (one that is in turn inspired by a relative who was a pioneer of the American conservation movement) and ending the book with advice on how readers can help prepare a better future for their children. Not only is this an excellent book for whoever cares about the environment and wants to learn more about practical actions to take better care of it, but it might even speak to those who don't feel that concerned, as Freeman does an excellent job explaining why a healthy salmon, or beaver, or frog is important to the whole community.[return]The copy I reviewed was an advance reading copy and therefore was missing some of the final illustrations, but I often wished the book included a map of the revitalized area, which would have helped visualize the narrative better.

books.title: Blood and Belonging
books.author: Delany, Vicki
books.notes: RCMP officer Ray Robertson is enjoying a well-earned vacation on Grand Turk island with his wife. Duty catches up with him when he finds a lifeless body on the beach one morning and realizes he has a connection with the victim.[return][return]This is an easy short read, good for an afternoon at the beach. The story is well paced, packing just enough social and personal drama mixed up with a little action to grapple the reader.

books.title: Old Ways,The: A Journey On Foot
books.author: Macfarlane, Robert
books.notes: I really wanted to like this book. I tried to pick it up several times but I found that I could never truly engage with the text. The subject is fascinating, I love walking and traveling, and I have several such "psychogeography" memoirs among my favourite books, but I found MacFarlane impossible to follow. The description of his travels are intertwined with lofty literature commentaries and historical innuendos that are too much for mere mortals like us. Also, why aren't there any maps in that book? A nice map of each trail could maybe have saved the book for me, but that was the last straw.

books.title: The Time Traveller's Resort and Museum
books.author: McLain, David
books.notes: Alice arrives in London to deliver a talk at the Royal Academy about the science podcast she co-hosts with totally-not-her-boyfriend Malcolm. But the night before the talk, Malcolm is mysteriously killed and Alice is framed for his murder. She manages to escape police enquiry with the help of a strangely dressed man she's pretty sure she's seeing for the first time but who seems strangely familiar with her. Have they met? And why does barmen who all look the same keep bringing her drinks she didn't order?[return][return]I found this nonsensical tale of time travel, the difficulty to maintain a stable relationship with a husband you haven't met yet and pet triceratops to be quite entertaining. The writing is a bit clumsy sometimes and the story could benefit from a few shortcuts, but it's a fun read nevertheless. [return][return]I read and enjoyed this book through the Early Reviewers program.

It's not as detailed as other food science books (think The Food Lab) and there are no recipes, instead it's intended as a practical guide for recipe development. For example: I want to thicken this sauce without compromising on flavour, what are my options?

books.title: The Mercy of the Tide
books.author: Rosson, Keith
books.notes: In Reagan's America, the Cold War is a palpable threat. But as the year 1983 nears to an end, the impending nuclear doom of the mutual assured destruction doctrine isn't the only shadow to darken the small coastal town of Riptide, Oregon. Mutilated animals start appearing, ancient remains are found that bring back memories of a violent past, before the town is shocked by the grueling death of a young man. Battling with demons on their own, the local sheriff and his deputies soon find that the key to what is happening might not be found among the living... And the rain never stops falling.[return][return]I was instantly grappled by this novel, which follows the lives of a handful of characters as they become more and more intertwined. Navigating in turn grief, boredom, lust, coming of age and raw guilt, each story is told with great sensibility and detail, slowly building the wider narrative, which grows progressively darker until the final climax. The result is a fascinating tale of loss and aching. A family ripped apart by a fatal accident, teenage angst, lust and love, the banal horrors of everyday life are soon replaced by more threatening elements, signs that Rosson's version of 1983 might be a bit different than the one from our memories.[return][return]As much as I enjoyed the dark side stories, I couldn't help but feel a bit disappointed by the main plot. The major story twist that is happening towards the end of the book could have been strong enough on its own without the extra supernatural and alternate history elements of the final chapters. But aside from this minor weakness, this is a strong story, of a quality that I've never before seen in the titles I've reviewed for the Early Reviewers program. I'm looking forward to more titles by this author.

books.title: Edible and Medicinal Plants of Canada

books.title: Shadow Courts: The Tribunals that Rule Global Trade
books.author: Edwards, Haley Sweetland
books.notes: This short and to the point book should be required reading for every parliamentarian involved in ratifying a bilateral investment treaty. It very convincingly highlights the issues introduced by a little-known clause of international trade treaties, Investor-State Dispute Settlement (ISDS), a supranational "arbitration" mechanism that allows a corporation to file a complaint against a country if a change in legislation "unfairly" undermines past investments.[return][return]The fundamental flaws of this mechanism are succinctly described, as is evidence of the growing number of cases in which it is abused for the maximization of corporate profits, often at the expense of developing countries. An urgent, important read, about a topic that mainstream media never talks about and few politicians even seem to be aware of. Do your country (and the world) a favour and send a copy of this book to your elected representatives next time a treaty is being negotiated.

books.title: Flour Water Salt Yeast: The Fundamentals of Artisan Bread and Pizza
books.author: Forkish, Ken

books.title: Freeze/Thaw
books.author: Bucholz, Chris
books.notes: Towards the end of the 21st century, the Earth is experiencing a new Ice Age because of the Shade, an array of objects placed in space by ecoterrorists to compensate global warming by reducing the amount of sunlight. As humanity struggles to survive, an attempt is made to regain control of the Shade by digging up a frozen research lab. As an expert in quantum computers, the narrator is part of the expedition. But his task is made harder by the fact that he is tetraplegic, and has to rely on an exoskeleton in order to function.[return][return]I found this novel to be enjoyable, with a good story and a coherent universe. Although it uses most of the usual tropes of post-apocalyptic literature, the unique position of the main character adds a welcome twist to the genre.[return][return]The version of the ebook that I received as part of the Early Reviewers program was missing the chapter markings. I first got surprised by some story jumps before I realized these were supposed to be narrative bridges between chapters. Hopefully the retail version of this title will have the chapters properly separated.

books.title: Weapons of Math Destruction: How Big Data Increases Inequality and Threatens Democracy
books.author: O'Neil, Cathy

books.title: Les Guetteurs du passé
books.author: Blanc, Yves
books.notes: Autant je suis un grand fan de la Planète Bleue, l'émission de radio animée par Yves Blanc, autant j'ai été déçu par son livre. Il ne s'agit pas tant d'un roman que d'une suite de saynètes répétant les thèmes chers à l'auteur. Sa critique sociale et écologique, dénonçant les ravages absurdes du consumérisme aveugle, est importante et mérite d'être dite. Malheureusement la forme choisie est plutôt maladroite et dessert le message. Un essai aurait peut être été plus efficace. Ou une émission de radio...

books.title: The Genius Asylum: Sic Transit Terra Book 1
books.author: Marks, Arlene F.
books.notes: When his best friend was found brutally murdered, Drew wasn't about to let anyone prevent him from conducting his own investigation. That is, until he's being sent to a remote space station as a double agent, to investigate another brutal death. Coincidence, or all part of the intricate power play between rivaling global security agencies?[return][return]This was an entertaining read, although I had trouble really engaging with the story. I found the main characters to be likeable and interesting, but the multiple story lines that the main character unveils as he makes its way through the confusing web of espionage spanning the story were hard to follow. The alien species' strange rituals and mysterious technology was a nice touch, but I found that it distracted the reader too much from the main elements of the story. But it's a nice universe and I wouldn't mind reading the next novel in the series.

books.notes: This is a nice little story about a junior reporter in Vancouver, Canada, who accidentally stumbles upon a mystery. It is a short, interesting read, although the topic and characters could do with a bit more depth. Asides from a few repetitions, it is a nice debut novella, and I look forward to see the sympathetic main character grow in complexity in future episodes, as the author develops her style!

books.title: The Unpleasantness at Baskerville Hall (Reeves & Worcester Steampunk Mysteries Book 4)
books.author: Dolley, Chris
books.notes: As a fan of P. G. Wodehouse's Jeeves and Wooster series, I approached this steampunk mash up of the (I thought) inimitable P. G. and Conan Doyle with wariness. I was wrong, as Chris Dolley does an excellent job recreating the lovable characters and frivolous atmosphere of the one with the fast-paced sleuthing of the second. Bertie Wooster becomes Reggie Worcester, consulting detective, flanked by the ever-tactful automaton Reeves. A handful of more steam-powered automata and "prometheans" spice up the story, enough to clearly depart from the original authors, yet not too much as to become overwhelming. The result is funny, brilliant, geeky, engrossing, and leaves the reader wanting for more! Plus, extra nerd cred for painting Edison as a distant malevolent creature.[return][return]I received a complimentary copy of this book through the Early Reviewers program, and this was my first foray into steampunk fan-fiction and the work of Chris Dolley. Hopefully this will not be my last, as I'm planning to read Reeves and Worcester's debut "What Ho, Automaton!" next.

books.title: The Neal-Schuman Library Technology Companion, Fourth Edition
books.author: Burke, John J.

books.title: Marcus Off Duty: The Recipes I Cook at Home
books.author: Samuelsson, Marcus

books.title: Between You & Me: Confessions of a Comma Queen
books.author: Norris, Mary

books.title: The Diagrams Book: 50 Ways to Solve Any Problem Visually
books.author: Duncan, Kevin
books.notes: The information value of this small book is very limited. It is a collection of the graphics that are commonly used to illustrate corporate presentations. The diagrams are presented with very little background and near-total ignorance of their mathematical backgrounds. Expect the kind of graphs depicting percentage values where the sum of the parts exceeds 100% and inaccurate timelines. These devices can possibly be used to get broad messages across to a non-technical audience, but don't expect to learn anything about how to display and visualize data.

books.title: Managing with Data: Using ACRLMetrics and PLAmetrics
books.author: Hernon, Peter

books.title: Melt: The Art of Macaroni and Cheese
books.author: Stiavetti, Stephanie

books.title: Combat-Ready Kitchen: How the U.S. Military Shapes the Way You Eat
books.author: Marx De Salcedo, Anastacia
books.notes: This book is a treasure trove of anecdotes about the sometimes unexpected provenance of the staples in our pantries. That the tin can was developed as a response to Napoleon's desire to replace his army's plundering with a more stable form of sustenance is well established. But the military's role, if not in the invention, then in the massive implementation of food sterilization techniques, packaging and esoteric preparation techniques did not stop there.[return]Most chapters of this book read well, arranged in chronological order and cleverly prefaced with short tableaus of modern family life to outline the ubiquitousness of the products discussed in the book. Unfortunately, their quality is uneven, alterning between well-researched popular science essays and rather confusing strings of anecdotes. Maybe this book is best enjoyed like a packaged Meal, Ready to Eat (MRE): devour the snacks and the more appetizing bits, but skip the soggy sides. Unless you are really hungry.

books.title: David Foster Wallace Ruined My Suicide: And Other Stories
books.author: Miller, D. D.

books.title: Fourth of July Creek: A Novel
books.author: Henderson, Smith

books.title: Station Eleven
books.author: Mandel, Emily St. John
books.notes: A winter in Toronto, a few hours before the apocalypse, a famous actor dies of a seizure in the middle of a performance of King Lear. Fifteen years later, survivors of the flu pandemic that nearly wiped out humanity join a caravan that performs Shakespeare plays, because "surviving is not enough".[return][return]This novel reads well and I quite liked the idea of the Travelling Symphony, a troupe of musicians and comedians performing Shakespeare among the ruins of civilization. I also enjoyed the scenes set in Toronto, my current home. To me, the subplots around the characters and their relationships before and after the pandemic are the most interesting part of the novel. I found the post-apocalyptic world described by Mandel to be much less believable than those of e.g. Edan Lepucki and Kim Stanley Robinson. Notably, I couldn't help but be irritated by survivors who, nearly twenty years after "the end of civilization" are still living in fast food joints, gas stations and tents set up in the middle of an airport terminal while leaving millions of empty houses abandoned. This reads more like a weak plot to highlight the contrast between survival after the catastrophe and the life of plenty that we took as granted, and less like a well-researched, plausible anticipation. The absence of any attempt to keep some of the pre-catastrophe technology working (other than guns) is also unnerving. Solar panels, anyone? Also, generators can run on something else than diesel.[return][return]In the end, these shortcomings, as well as the rather hollow ending, left me slightly disappointed, and yearning for a truly believable (and thus much more sobering) post-apocalyptic novel.

books.title: War Plan Red: The United States' Secret Plan to Invade Canada and Canada's Secret Plan to Invade the United States
books.author: Lippert, Kevin
books.notes: The first half of this fairly short book reviews the history of the border skirmishes between the USA and Canada. The second half contains a facsimile of the World War II era plans for mutual annexation mentioned in the title.[return][return]The stories collected in the first part range from the real battles of the War of 1812, to more symbolic power plays in the contemporary "War on Terror". Unfortunately, the WWII plans that are mentioned in the title are not treated in more detail than the other anecdotes, which is disappointing given the book's title. The stories are written in a light tone, which is fitting to the largely comical aspects of the US-Canada border issues. However, this tone also makes it hard to follow and understand the stories, especially for readers not already familiar with the events.

books.title: Red Sky at Night: The Book of Lost Countryside Wisdom
books.author: Struthers, Jane
books.notes: This delightful collection of odds and ends of British countryside wisdom make for a perfect read at the end of a long day, by the fireside. Or while drinking tea, or enjoying a glass of wine on the porch while the apple sauce thickens. Short bits of timeless wisdom, some useful (like a handful of recipes for jams and syrups, or lists of the best types of wood to burn in your chimney), other of less practical use (like the rules of fox hunting and where in Britain the practice of cheese rolling is still current). Delightful indeed.

books.title: Qu'il est bon d'être mauvais
books.author: Connard, L'Odieux
books.notes: Quelle déception! Autant je trouve le blog de l'Odieux Connard fin et délectable, autant j'ai été déçu par ce bouquin plat et navrant. Privé de son fond de commerce dans lequel il excelle (la critique de film hollywoodien et le commentaire politique - le retour de Jean Jaurès est un vrai chef d'oeuvre), l'Odieux se perd dans le gag bête et méchant, et le préjugé bon marché. Mieux vaut oublier cet ouvrage le plus vite possible et se replonger avec délices dans les archives du blog.

books.title: The Martian
books.author: Weir, Andy
books.notes: The Martian relates the race for survival of an astronomer stranded on Mars after his team left the planet in a hurry, fleeing a nasty sand storm. His engineering knowledge comes in handy as he reorganizes the martian station, originally planned for a short stay only, to sustain his life while NASA tries one harebrained plan after another to come and rescue him. The novel comes close to what every science fiction book should be: plausible, well-researched science, relatable characters, page-turning action. Sadly, it doesn't avoid the usual pitfalls of the genre either, such as sexist gallows humour and the common deification of the white male american rule-bending hero. Fortunately, since social aspects play here a decidedly second role behind the intricate science and engineering of survival, the novel remains enjoyable all the way to the end. A good nerdy read.

books.title: Places of the Heart: The Psychogeography of Everyday Life
books.author: Ellard, Colin
books.notes: Psychogeography, it its modern definition, is the study of the effect of the natural and built environment on human psychology. In his book, Ellard explores that relationship by focusing on different emotions (comfort, desire, fear, awe, etc.). Although natural landscapes and early human settlements are mentioned in passing, the modern urban environment is Ellard's main focus.[return][return]The book serves the dual purpose of presenting Ellard's own research results, and providing the state of the art on the psychogeography of cities by citing other studies and authors. It is therefore aimed both to the general public interested in the topic and to scholars. This is a difficult endeavour, and Ellard is careful to balance rigor with enjoyable reading, with unequal results. Some chapters read well, and are enjoyable to the layperson, while others are more dry and hard to follow. Unfortunately, the book starts with a rather dry chapter, which can dampen the reader's enthusiasm. Plowing through is rewarding, however, as the text is replete with fascinating examples ofthe intended and, often, unintended effects the built environment has on its inhabitants.[return][return]Nevertheless, I would recommend this book to anyone that is interested in psychogeography, and particularly urban planners, designers and architects intent on better understanding our relationship to the city.

books.title: The Ocean at the End of the Lane: A Novel
books.author: Gaiman, Neil

books.title: Facts and Fallacies of Software Engineering
books.author: Glass, Robert L.

books.title: Better Homes and Gardens Kitchen and Bath Renovation Guide (Better Homes and Gardens Home)
books.author: Better Homes and Gardens

books.title: A Bunch of Pretty Things I Did Not Buy
books.author: Lazarovic, Sarah

books.title: Service Design: From Insight to Implementation
books.author: Polaine, Andy

books.title: Digital Paper: A Manual for Research and Writing with Library and Internet Materials (Chicago Guides to Writing, Editing, and Publishing)
books.author: Abbott, Andrew

books.title: Wild Ones: A Sometimes Dismaying, Weirdly Reassuring Story About Looking at People Looking at Animals in America
books.author: Mooallem, Jon

books.title: Go: A Kidd's Guide to Graphic Design
books.author: Kidd, Chip

books.title: Ce livre devrait me permettre de résoudre le conflit au Proche-Orient, d'avoir mon diplôme et de trouver une femme : Tome 2
books.author: Mazas, Sylvain

books.title: Hipster Business Models: How to make a living in the modern world
books.author: Priceonomics

books.title: The Shambling Guide to New York City (The Shambling Guides)
books.author: Lafferty, Mur

books.title: The Knowledge: How to Rebuild Our World from Scratch
books.author: Dartnell, Lewis

books.title: The Teleportation Accident
books.author: Beauman, Ned
books.notes: A very original and very entertaining novel, brimming with sophistication, vainness and the insatiable desire of a young intellectual who hasn't got laid in a long time. It's a whimsical mix of several genres. Even if situated in a recognisable timeframe, the book is filled with tiny historical inaccuracies that somehow all serve to make the world in which the novel unfurls even more unbelievably realistic. Supernatural elements turn out to be quite banal fabrications while sound science reveals dark Lovecraftian mysteries. Literal references abound, historical figures mix with complete fabrications and recurring characters predictably turn out where they're the least expected. Somber historical events are treated lightly but with respect. I don't often laugh out loud when I read, but this one had me giggling on my subway seat. Truly genius.

books.title: The Sixth Extinction: An Unnatural History
books.author: Kolbert, Elizabeth

books.title: The Tastemakers: Why We're Crazy for Cupcakes but Fed Up with Fondue
books.author: Sax, David

books.title: What If?: Serious Scientific Answers to Absurd Hypothetical Questions
books.author: Munroe, Randall

books.title: Wallpaper* City Guide London 2014 (Wallpaper City Guides)
books.author: Wallpaper*

books.title: Ce Livre Devrait Me Permettre de Resoudre le Conflit au Proche-Orient, d'Avoir Mon Diplôme et de Trouver une femme
books.author: Mazas, Sylvain

books.title: Packing for Mars: The Curious Science of Life in the Void
books.author: Roach, Mary

books.title: Gulp: Adventures on the Alimentary Canal
books.author: Roach, Mary

books.title: The Little Book of Hindu Deities: From the Goddess of Wealth to the Sacred Cow
books.author: Patel, Sanjay

books.title: SPSS for Psychologists: A Guide to Data Analysis Using SPSS for Windows
books.author: Brace, Nicola

books.title: How to Fake a Moon Landing: Exposing the Myths of Science Denial
books.author: Cunningham, Darryl

books.title: Ramayana: Divine Loophole
books.author: Patel, Sanjay
books.notes: This version of the Ramayana, abridged and illustrated by Sanjay Patel, is a very enjoyable and visual introduction to the great Hindu epic tale. Using simple everyday words and evocative art, Patel creates a narrative that appeals to all generations and cultures. A very handy guide to all the characters of the story is provided at the end of the book. While the text can sometimes verge on the simplistic, the beautiful illustrations more than adequately redeem this. I can't wait to read the other adaptations of Hindu mythology by the same author!

books.title: The Confession
books.author: Grisham, John
books.notes: Clearly not the best Grisham, but nevertheless touching on an important topic. The story is quite linear and straightforward, and works as an undisguised medium to carry the author's condemnation of the death penalty. While a valuable enterprise, the feeble storytelling is unworthy of all the other Grisham books I've read.

books.title: The Everything Store: Jeff Bezos and the Age of Amazon
books.author: Stone, Brad

books.title: Shady Characters: The Secret Life of Punctuation, Symbols, and Other Typographical Marks
books.author: Houston, Keith

books.title: Wallpaper City Guide: Montreal (Wallpaper City Guides)
books.author: Magazine, Editors of Wallpaper

books.title: David and Goliath: Underdogs, Misfits, and the Art of Battling Giants
books.author: Gladwell, Malcolm

books.title: Geek Sublime
books.author: Chandra, Vikram
books.notes: Is computer programming an art? Through his dual experience as a successful computer programmer and author of fiction, Chandra is perfectly situated to tackle this complex issue. In this fascinating memoir, he draws a parallel between programming languages and the intricate grammatical rules of Sanskrit, which arguably played an instrumental role in the establishment of the algorithmic principles that eventually evolved into computer instructions. Although the first chapters on the principles and history of coding are brilliantly eloquent - as is the very convincing critic of the inherent machismo of the IT community - the rest of the book quickly evolves into a rather dense discussion of literature aesthetics. And eventually leads to a bittersweet conclusion: code is code, it ultimately exists for a purpose. The intrinsic elegance of a computer program will only be perceptible by a very select group of human beings, as in, arguably, literature. But that is all right, for the true beauty both of a computer program and a good book lies more in how if affects the life of the user/reader than in arcane language rules. Who can object to that after a hundred pages of Sanskrit theory?

books.title: L' extraordinaire voyage du fakir qui était resté coincé dans une armoire Ikéa
books.author: Puertolas, Romain

books.title: The Skies Belong to Us: Love and Terror in the Golden Age of Hijacking
books.author: Koerner, Brendan I.

books.title: Unbuilt Toronto 2: More of the City That Might Have Been
books.author: Osbaldeston, Mark

books.title: Unbuilt Toronto: A History of the City That Might Have Been
books.author: Osbaldeston, Mark

books.title: Concrete Toronto: A Guide to Concrete Architecture from the Fifties to the Seventies
books.author: McClelland, Michael

books.title: Historical Atlas of Toronto
books.author: Hayes, Derek
books.notes: This is a superb collection of maps documenting the entire history of the city of Toronto. Starting with a First Nation map drawn on birchbark and the first European map of the area, the Huron Map drawn by a French explorer in 1641 to a contemporary satellite image, carefully researched maps portray the history of the city in a uniquely visual way. Although most maps speak to themselves, they are accompanied by just the right amount of text to place them into context. The author is also thankfully generous in his definition of what a map is, allowing him to use birds eye views, drawings and photographs to better illustrate the transformation of the city.[return][return]New to the city myself (and, admittedly, rather a map geek too), I have learned a great deal just by browsing this excellent book. Names, geographical features, road layouts make much more sense to me now that I learned how they came to be. For example, I realized that a street in my neighborhood called "Indian Road" is so named because it follows an ancient path used by the Mississauga Nation long before the first settlers came to the shores of Lake Ontario. As the settlement, then the city grew, it spread its network of roads around this ancient path, connecting modern urban design with age-old wisdom. It's easy to forget how much a city grows organically. Studying historical maps is a great way to bring that fact back to life.

books.title: Information Ecology: Mastering the Information and Knowledge Environment
books.author: Davenport, Thomas H.

books.title: Getting Started with Arduino
books.author: Banzi, Massimo
books.notes: Good primer for non-techies. Everything is kept at a very, very simple level and assumes no prior knowledge in electronics or computer programming. It is not a manual or a complete reference, but an easy text that tries to provide instant-gratification with a few simple sample circuits and in the process foster the curiosity of the reader.

books.title: CLOG: Brutalism
books.author: Clog
books.notes: This well-curated and artfully composed collection of essays - CLOG's trademark - is a balanced take on the complex issues raised by the current regain of interest for brutalist architecture. However, I found it less accessible for non-architects than other CLOG issues, too many arcane references..

books.title: Die schönsten Bauten 1960-75 von Otterlo zur Ölkrise / Les plus beaux bâtiments 1960-75 d'Otterlo à la crise pétrolière
books.author: Baciu, Dan Costa

books.title: Toronto Architecture: A City Guide (Revised & Expanded)
books.author: McHugh, Patricia

books.title: Dixon Grace: 1.9.7 Hamburg
books.author: Camouro, Alexa
books.notes: On the surface, Dixie is just another young expatriate in Hamburg, teaching English to corporate clients. She wouldn't miss her native Australia so much if only Germans knew how to build a proper cricket field... Below the surface, well, things are different.[return][return]This book is interestingly structured, I loved the constant back and forth between times and characters, which I found a very original way of progressively revealing the story. Unfortunately, the novelty wears thin after the first few hundred pages, and it soon becomes quite hard to follow the plot. This, and the absence of a proper closure chapter at the end left me with too many unanswered questions to properly enjoy this book. Thriller readers want closure, the ability to understand the plot at the end, an opportunity to compare notes with what they had already found out by themselves and a last chance to grasp plot details that they might have overseen. No such luck here. I found myself still wondering what was the exact connection between the many stories interwoven in this book, and the motives for many of the characters actions still elude me.[return][return]Still, it was a good read, one of those thrillers you just can't put away. The expat's point of view of life in northern Germany was a nice addition, too.

books.title: A Guidebook to Contemporary Architecture in Toronto
books.author: Goodfellow, Margaret

books.title: Full Frontal T.O.: Exploring Toronto's Architectural Vernacular
books.author: Micallef, Shawn

books.title: Scatter, Adapt, and Remember: How Humans Will Survive a Mass Extinction
books.author: Newitz, Annalee

books.title: Disappearance of Darkness: Photography at the End of the Analog Era
books.author: Burley, Robert
books.notes: Not far from my home in Toronto, Canada, lies a road called Photography Drive. After driving by its sign several times, intrigued (I'm new in town), I researched where the name came from and learned that until 2005, that road led to a large Kodak film manufacturing plant. Of the once sprawling industrial complex, only one building remains standing today. The dilapidated shell of the former Kodak employee centre is a striking reminder of how sudden the death of analogue photography came.[return][return]A professor at Ryerson University in Toronto and an experienced photographer, Robert Burley lived the global demise of the film giants firsthand. The Disappearance of Darkness is the result of a decade spent documenting the end of an era. From Kodak Heights in Toronto, Burley traveled the world to fixate - on photographic film - the remains of a once formidable industry. To any photographer, his impeccable, almost clinical images are both a delight in exposing an industrial process that used to be veiled in secrecy, and a distressing reminder that this very secrecy means that an immense body of knowledge was irremediably lost in the rapid dismantlement of film-processing plants... [return][return]Burley invites the reader to reflect on the past but doesn't limit himself to a nostalgic backward glance. Photography is not dead, it has evolved. Photographic film is not dead either, it moved from a mass staple to a niche product. This is a good book, and all good books end with a message: that of putting it back on the shelf after reading, going out, and taking a few more photographs.

books.title: Exploding the Phone: The Untold Story of the Teenagers and Outlaws who Hacked Ma Bell
books.author: Lapsley, Phil
books.notes: This book is a quite detailed history of the rise of phone phreaking from the early 50s until the dawn of the 80s, with an entertaining mix of anecdotal, historical and technical details. Phone exploits are explained with just the amount of precision to make satisfy the technically minded yet without delving into tediousness. It also provides a nice background into the history of the telephone, and the evolution of its network in the USA.[return][return]While I enjoyed learning more about early telephone technology and the almost mythical phone phreaks that were the ancestors of computer hackers, I still found this book a bit tedious to read, especially after the first two thirds or thereabouts. There seems to be too much emphasis on the FBI investigations agains the phreaks and their sometimes pathetic response, compared on the first chapters on technological history and the discovery of various telephone exploits.

books.title: Elle portait un manteau rouge
books.author: Crevoisier, Pierre
books.notes: Cette histoire commence par la fin. Celle d'un homme brisé, laissant derrière lui une enveloppe scellée et un journal. C'est au travers des pages de ce dernier que le frère de la victime, et avec lui le lecteur, revit la rencontre dévastatrice entre une femme abîmée et cet homme qui le sera bientôt. En parallèle, une autre histoire se faufile, celle d'une enfance perdue. Lorsque les deux récits se rencontrent, la fin est proche.[return][return]Avec ce drame psychologique d'une violence sourde, Pierre Crevoisier signe avec brio son premier roman. C'est fort, dur et poétique, de la même poésie que celle qui décrirait le vol, suspendu, d'une feuille morte avant qu'elle ne soit happée par un train rapide, broyée sans merci sous mille tonnes de métal hurlant. Ça pourrait se lire d'une traite, s'il n'était le besoin parfois de respirer, de regarder autour de soi pour s'assurer que le monde est aussi capable de douceur.[return][return]J'ai la chance de connaître Pierre de l'autre côté des lignes. J'ai vu naître ce roman, de loin, entrevu la dame en rouge avant de la connaître. J'étais loin de me douter de la force de ce récit. Pierre, bravo.

books.title: Stroll: Psychogeographic Walking Tours of Toronto
books.author: Micallef, Shawn
books.notes: Do you love Toronto and walking, sorry, strolling? Or hate Toronto but don't mind getting your feet dirty? Or can't imagine walking further than the nearest coffee shop in this city you can't help but love? Either way, this book is for you. Shawn Micallef will have you look where you've never looked before, discover beauty in brutalist facades, history behind corporate storefronts, culture where no Starbucks has ever set a latte.[return][return]I like walking, and I've been out discovering the city on foot ever since I moved to Toronto, but it's only after reading Stroll that I realized how much I had been missing of the cityscape. How, as a newcomer, I had failed to realize that even the most modern building always has a history worth telling. Micallef's love for Toronto permeates his writing, and like a seasoned lover, he is keenly aware of both the most striking features and the most embarrassing shortcomings of his city. Which makes it even more sympathetic to the reader. So grab a copy of this book and go out. Now![return][return]Dirty secret: Stroll is actually quite enjoyable to the armchair Torontonian, too.[return][return]Bonus: as of the time of this writing, Micallef is one of the writers in residence at the Toronto Public Library, and is organizing free guided tours of the city. I for one am signed up for the next one!

books.title: The Graphic Canon, Vol. 1: From the Epic of Gilgamesh to Shakespeare to Dangerous Liaisons
books.author: Kick, Russ

books.title: Fast Food Nation: The Dark Side of the All-American Meal
books.author: Schlosser, Eric

books.title: Apnée
books.author: Zviane
books.notes: Apnée, c'est l'histoire d'un vide avec un goût d'eau. Ce récit simple et poignant raconte la difficile remontée à la surface de Sophie après sa dépression. Magnifiquement illustrées et magistralement composées, comme autant de plans de cinéma, les pages entraînent le lecteur avec délicatesse, accompagnant Sophie dans sa névrose présciente... Du grand art.

books.title: Dieter Rams: As Little Design as Possible
books.author: Lovell, Sophie

books.title: Winning: Reflections on an American Obsession
books.author: Duina, Francesco
books.notes: Winning aims to explore the quintessentially American obsession with competition and explore why it might not be the best approach towards happiness. However, do not expect a self-help book: this is a dry sociology essay and therefore, it is rather dull to the casual reader... I, for one, was largely disappointed by this book because I was hoping to find confirmation for my personal reluctance to competition in all aspects of life. Instead, I found myself struggling to keep interested in the text.[return][return]The book starts quite tantalizingly with the realization that Danes report being much happier than Americans, while also displaying a cultural reluctance to competition. One would therefore expect the rest of the essay to explore the all-American winning culture with a critical approach. Instead of that, the text goes on into an incredibly tedious dissection of the various aspects of competition, heaping meaningless examples on top of apparent common sense. Only in the concluding chapter does the author come back to its initial comparison with Denmark, acknowledges the apparent contradiction and even goes so far as to propose three alternate approaches that could bring Americans closer to happiness without forfeiting their love for the Super Bowl.[return][return]As far as I was concerned, the first and last chapters were the only ones of interest in this book. Even then, I didn't find the concluding suggestions for a happier life exactly Earth-shattering either. In a nutshell, we would all be better off by a) practicing "conceptual hygiene", that is using the language of winning only when pursuing victory at something and avoiding it when comparing ourselves with others. Then we could also start realizing that b) the way really is the goal and that the process of achieving something the right way matters more than the actual result. Finally, we might as well c) ensure that we only engage in activities that "satisfy our true and genuine drives and needs". Now you tell me.[return][return]Maybe it was my Swiss upbringing talking (very close to the Danish Jante's Law in that it convinced me that under no circumstance I was to consider myself better than anyone else), but I very vividly remembers applying those exact three principles when arguing with my sports teacher that being last didn't matter to me in the slightest and that I really preferred to leisurely walk around the soccer field rather than waste my energy running...

books.title: Bankrupting Physics: How Today's Top Scientists are Gambling Away Their Credibility
books.author: Unzicker, Alexander
books.notes: This essay aims to shed light on the many shortenings of modern theoretical physics in a way that is understandable by the layman. With this goal in mind, the author walks its audience through the major theories currently accepted by the scientific establishment (string theory, dark matter, the Higgs boson, etc.) and proceeds to expose their fragility. "Renegade" physicists are called to the witness stand to back the book's claims.[return][return]Whether the author is right or wrong on all his claims are not for me to judge. His sobering accounts on peer pressure within the scientific community, the desperate need for scholars to "publish or perish" and their understandable bias towards high-profile experiments that are tied to large funding budgets are certainly accurate and resonate well with my own experience as a researcher (not in physics, I hasten to add). However, I found the text somewhat hard to follow. Complex theories are explained in an off-hand style that assumes a prior understanding of the main concepts. Furthermore, the silly anecdotes and raging anti-establishment rants that permeate the text are very distracting. The result is quite a laborious read. A shorter essay, concentrating on the most prominent theoretical shortcomings would have been much more efficient, in my opinion.

books.title: The Hipless Boy
books.author: Sully
books.notes: Sully lives in a hipster neighborhood in Montréal, but doesn't identify with the dominant culture. He's not a hipster, he's just the "hipless boy", caught between two relationships and coming to terms with his (occasionnally cross-dressed) life as a graphic artist. The stories in this collection are short insights in Sully's mostly uneventful life, pranks and conversations with his colorful friends Minerva the bisexual private-school dropout and Owen the happenings artist.[return][return]Apart from the truly gorgeous illustrations, what redeems all these relatively flat stories is the subtile way in which they touch on deeper, broader subjects, such as sexual identity, coming of age, social inequity or even teenage suicide. Intimist, sweet and a delight to the eyes, Sully's stories leave the reader with a desire to read more.

books.title: Fluffy
books.author: Lia, Simone
books.notes: This very original story hides a complex meaning beneath a seemingly absurd, childish tale. Fluffy the bunny is the not quite metaphorical child of Michael, who flees Britain to his parents' house in Sicily to escape a demanding girlfriend (and avoid questioning his meaningless life). Reuniting with his dysfunctional family and thanks to the gentle probing of his bunny-child, Michael somehow finds the inspiration to get on with his life.

books.title: Anagrammes renversantes ou Le sens caché du monde
books.author: Klein, Etienne

books.title: Mort au Café Romand et autres nouvelles
books.author: Urban, Matthias
books.notes: Les nouvelles de Matthias Urban mettent en scène des personnages atypiques dans des situations improbables, du macabre au rocambolesque, en passant par le surréaliste. En arrière-plan, une Suisse Romande plus fantasmée que réelle. L'auteur est comédien, et sa familiarité avec le théâtre se ressent dans ses nouvelles, qui sont autant de saynètes dont le décor est joliment construit.[return][return]Le style s'inspire des grandes voix de la littérature romande et les élans ramusiens font souvent surface. Malheureusement, là où un Ramuz ou un Chessex font preuve d'une connaissance approfondie de leur région, les approximations géographiques de Matthias Urban font peine à lire. Pourtant chef-lieux du canton du Jura, Delémont se retrouve ainsi au rang de "gros bourg vaudois", le patois des prétendus Nicod de Bottens semble avoir plus longtemps macéré dans le Bourgogne que le Dézaley et tout les curés qui peuplent ces récits auraient bien du mal à trouver le chemin de leur cure dans le Pays de Vaud ancestral (et traditionnellement protestant) que les récits tentent d'invoquer.[return][return]Enfin le crime le plus noir de tout l'ouvrage sera celui commis par l'auteur lui-même à la page 12, négligeant d'une faute de débutant LA règle grammaticale à ne pas transgresser en pays lémanique, distinguant immédiatement le vrai poète vaudois du vulgaire imposteur. Je laisse au lecteur le soin de trouver l'erreur infâme, n'osant pas ici la répéter de peur d'en alimenter la réputation Googelienne.[return][return]La couleur locale, c'est bien, mais avec l'accent parisien, ça passe moins bien.

books.title: Developing Library and Information Center Collections (Library and Information Science Text Series)
books.author: Evans, G. Edward

books.title: Managing Information Resources in Libraries: Collction Management in Theory and Practice
books.author: Clayton, Peter

books.title: The Female Ward
books.author: Haldar, Debalina
books.notes: This is the story of three female college students in India that have been wrongly accused of ragging other students and are sent to jail. If the novel is indeed based on real events, as claimed by the author, then it's a very sad and discouraging account of the injustices and violations of basic human rights that are still perpetrated in 21st century India.[return][return]Sadly, it is doubtful whether this novel will do much to change the situation. Especially since it is rather badly written and fails to convey much emotion about the events. The naïvety with which the narrator relates her story is staggering and also undermines the seriousness of the matter.[return][return]In a nutshell: important, powerful subject but weakly told.

books.title: At Home: A Short History of Private Life
books.author: Bryson, Bill
books.notes: This is a thoroughly enjoyable foray into domestic history and the dramatic changes brought by the Industrial Revolution. Bryson excells in illustrating history with quirky facts and colorful characters, and his deadpan style makes this rather long book enjoyable from start to finish.

books.title: Jérôme K. Jérôme Bloche - L'intégrale, Tome 1 :
books.author: Dodier, Alain

books.title: The Associate
books.author: Grisham, John
books.notes: Like all Grisham thrillers, this is a good page-turner and won't last long on your bedside table. But this one comes disappointingly short compared to his other novels. The characters lack depth, the story is rather straightforward, and the conclusion is entirely, almost depressingly expected. The book is replete with the usual law-firm clichés : ginormous salaries, abusive billing, staggering work hours... so much that the actual intrigue almost becomes a side story at times. Yawn.

books.title: Friends with Boys
books.author: Hicks, Faith Erin
books.notes: This refreshing teenage graphic novel nicely explores the intricacies of high school friendship, family dynamics, and social integration. The story is well constructed and superbly illustrated, and manages to veer clear of the usual young adult subjects (first love, dysfunctional families, and the like). I agree with other reviewers that the ghost figure doesn't really add much to the story, but it's a nice twist after all. A good read (for older readers too)!

books.title: Angel Baby: A Novel
books.author: Lange, Richard
books.notes: This is a well constructed thriller, with enough story twists to keep the pages turning until the last one. Maybe not the thickest or the most believable characters in the genre history, and a rather predictable ending, but the author keeps a trove of surprises for the reader as how to get there... I enjoyed reading the story, especially since it was a welcome break from the nonfiction I recently went through. Good, easy read.

books.title: The Botany of Desire: A Plant's-Eye View of the World
books.author: Pollan, Michael

books.title: French Milk
books.author: Knisley, Lucy
books.notes: French Milk relates the month the author spent visiting Paris with her mother. In her early twenties, embarking on a career in the graphic arts, Knisley tries to reconcile the many things that are happening to her and going through her mind as she visits the city, sightseeing, shopping, but mostly eating.[return][return]The episodes related in this graphic memoir are mostly trivial, and the naive, quintessentially american approach of Paris gets a little annoying over time, but these shortcomings are thankfully redeemed by Knisley's excellent graphical skills.[return][return]As for me, although I was never really fond of Paris (mostly because of execrable Parisiens), I felt a tang of nostalgia reading this book after nine months away from home in Europe. And pining for some real butter croissants, proper bread and plenty of cheese :)

books.title: Geektastic: Stories from the Nerd Herd
books.author: Black, Holly

books.title: Relish: My Life in the Kitchen
books.author: Knisley, Lucy
books.notes: Relish is a coming-of-age graphic memoir, tracing the author's relationship with food, which always played a large role in her life, mostly through her mother's cooking. The episodes are set in chronological order, from the author's childhood to her present young adult life, and are inter-sped with lovely illustrated recipes.[return][return]I first came upon Lucy Knisley's work at the Toronto Comic Arts Festival this year, and I instantly liked her style of drawing and storytelling. The illustrated recipes in particular drew my attention, as I found them very similar to the work of the French illustrator Guillaume Long which I've been following for quite a while. However, the similarity stops there, as her general aesthetic is closer to that of contemporary american illustrators such as Alison Bechdel or Raina Telgemeier. I'm looking forward to discovering more of her work!

books.title: Tango in Madeira: A Dance of Life, Love and Death
books.author: Williams, Jim
books.notes: When the steamer 'The Kildonian Castle' calls at the small British-held island of Madeira, most of the passengers alighting expect only a brief layover before continuing their route to South Africa. But a mysterious saboteur prevents the 'Castle' from continuing its journey, and its stranded passengers find themselves in the midst of a flurry of strange events. A man that is clearly a newcomer to the island yet that nobody recalls seeing on the ship is murdered in broad daylight, an angel appears on a stormy night, a porcelain cup disappears from its owner's collection, and there is talk of the exiled Austria-Hungarian Emperor being menaced by vengeful assassins...[return][return]This baroque novel is a true delight to read. Told from the point of view of a veteran soldier and ruined British wine merchant of dubious morals, the story slowly unfolds its unexpected twists amongst quirky characters, with the decadence of a post-WWI British colony in the background, all the while bein infused by dark humor and a thoughtful reflection on the state of man after a ghastly war. Brilliant, entertaining, droll, and serious.

books.title: Rules of Murder (A Drew Farthering Mystery)
books.author: Deering, Julianna
books.notes: Somewhere in the English countryside in the 1930s, a party comes to an abrupt end when the corpse of a dinner guest is found in the greenhouse. Notwithstanding the police inspector dispatched to the scene, the young heir of the manor, Drew, his friend Nick and Madeline, a visiting American, decide to conduct their own investigation...[return][return]Written in the style of the classic English mystery, this story sadly fails to create the unmistakable atmosphere of a good Agatha Christie novel. Its writing is cumbersome and laden with clichés, and despite the important body count, the intrigue never really picks up. The romantic involvement of Drew and Madeline is impossibly sexist and downright puritan, not to mention boring: what good love story is resolved in the first ten pages, leaving the two characters meekly exchanging platitudes for the rest of the story? Religious undertones further add to the story's clumsiness, making up for a rather disappointing read.

books.title: Burning the Page: The eBook revolution and the future of reading
books.author: Merkoski, Jason

books.title: Love in the Time of Algorithms: What Technology Does to Meeting and Mating
books.author: Slater, Dan

books.title: Minimalist Parenting: Enjoy Modern Family Life More by Doing Less
books.author: Koh, Christine

books.title: The Amazing Adventures of Kavalier & Clay
books.author: Chabon, Michael

books.title: The Expats: A Novel
books.author: Pavone, Chris
books.notes: The Expats is an espionage novel with a few interesting twists. The main character is a young mother, apparently renouncing her job in administration to follow her husband on a lucrative job abroad, but she is in fact an ex-CIA agent and her new life as a housewife contrasts sharply with her glamorous past. Thankfully, she hasn’t lost her acuity and is quick to find out that something is very strange about his husband’s new job. And what about those all-too-friendly fellow expats?[return][return]The fact that the main character is a powerful woman is a nice change from the usual espionage novels. Plus, the contrast between her struggle to keep up taking care of her family while conducting her personal investigation is another thing I liked in that book. Finally, it gave a pretty good description of what it’s like to move to a foreign country…

books.title: Visit Sunny Chernobyl: And Other Adventures in the World's Most Polluted Places
books.author: Blackwell, Andrew

books.title: Potatoes: From Mash to Fries
books.author: Nichols, Annie
books.notes: I was a bit disappointed by this book, especially about the photography: not all recipes are illustrated, and the ones that are appear somewhat faded and unappetizing. The recipes' presentation is not always very convenient, some of them even have the ingredients written on the previous page from the recipe, requiring constant page turning. Most dishes are quite conventional, with a few interesting variations that are sadly not enough put forward. All in all, some useful inspirations but otherwise quite a boring book. That's a pity, for the potato is anything but boring!

books.title: The Korean Table: From Barbecue to Bibimbap 100 Easy-To-Prepare Recipes
books.author: Samuels, Debra
books.notes: Korean food is on its way to become my favorite asian fare. I love the bold tastes, balanced spices and the delicacy with which korean food is usually prepared and presented. And I'm totally addicted to kimchi. This book gives excellent credit to the korean table: its recipes are clearly explained, entertainingly introduced and expertly illustrated with mouth-watering photos. I liked the way the essential ingredients are introduced at the beginning of the book, and I loved the story behind the book, about how the two authors met. Great, yummy book.

books.title: The Farm: Rustic Recipes for a Year of Incredible Food
books.author: Knauer, Ian

books.title: Work the Pond! Use the Power of Positive Networking to Leap Forward in Work and Life
books.author: Rezac, Darcy
books.notes: Many of us professionals are nervous about networking. We understand the rationale behind it and recognize its theoretical usefulness, but quite frankly rarely enjoy ourselves doing it. Facing a roomful of strangers, we'd rather be home reading a good book (preferably not one about networking). Rezac has the honesty to recognize that not everyone is a natural networker. Sadly, he didn't do a good job making it any easier, by insisting on techniques that any person with a propension for introversion will find downright aggressive. And they are pretty straightforward: go to as many networking events as possible, talk with as many strangers as possible, get your business cards working (Rezac is a huge fan of business cards). Not tremendously helpful.

books.title: Data, A Love Story: How I Gamed Online Dating to Meet My Match
books.author: Webb, Amy
books.notes: This book has benefited from a rather massive marketing campaign, it even has a movie trailer. The problem is that once you've seen the trailer, you don't need to read the book anymore because there's nothing more there. If you really want more after seeing the trailer, look for Webb's TEDx talk. It's 20 minutes long, about 15 more than what was necessary to drive her point. And there's still nothing more in the book.[return]Oh, it is an entertaining read, to an extend. The underlaying personal story is reminiscent of many chick-lit story lines and can be funny at times, but don't expect any groundbreaking insights. Webb did not "hack" online dating, she simply learned how to use it like a normal human being. And the "scientific" approach she claims to have used turns out to be more applied common sense than advanced calculus.

books.title: The DAM Book: Digital Asset Management for Photographers
books.author: Krogh, Peter
books.notes: This is a great resource for any photographer, amateur or professional, who is serious about properly managing a large digital collection. It extensively covers the most important aspects of a digital photography workflow, from getting the pictures into a computer in an orderly fashion, to managing files, handling metadata, backups, data migration and recovery. Readers that might not feel the need to implement all of the DAM protocols outlined in this book will nevertheless profit from the insights on backup, disk arrays, duplicates management and metadata.[return]My review is based on the second edition of this book (May 2009), which has obviously been updated to cover more recent software, and therefore solve most of the issues that have been pointed out in older reviews. Specifically, references to iView have been updated with MS Expression Engine and there is broad coverage of Lightroom-based workflows.

books.title: Day Trips from Toronto: Getaway Ideas for the Local Traveller (Day Trips Series)
books.author: Orr, Barbara Ramsay
books.notes: This guidebook contains some interesting pointers to potential destinations around Toronto, especially useful for people that are not familiar to the area. This being said, the proposed destinations are rarely graced with much details, the author preferring to dwell on how to get there (this in the century of GPS and Google Maps). The restaurants and accommodation options recommended tend to be on the pricier side, and the shopping section seems mostly to reflect the author's taste for stained glass. [return]There are no photographs whatsoever in this book. The image on the cover is the only want you'll see inside the book, repeated - in black and white - at the start of every chapter. Not tremendously useful to picture what to expect.

books.title: The Dying of the Light: Interval
books.author: Kristopher, Jason
books.notes: This is my very first foray into zombie stories, and I must admit I was pleasantly surprised, as there is more emphasis on survival and loyalty issues among the leftover humans, and not too much of the gory details I was fearing. Still, it remains a pretty mediocre action novel, with simplistic "good guy/bad guy" characters, an awful lot of trigger-happy military talk and not much consistency in technical or character details. [return]Or maybe I'm just too old for this.[return]I found it not absolutely necessary to have read the prior novel in the series to understand this one. Quite strangely, the first few chapters read like an independent story, with all elements properly introduced, and it's the later chapters that are full of unexplained references to the first volume.

books.title: La Réforme
books.author: Stauffer, Richard
books.notes: L'auteur de ce "Que sais-je" fait partie des historiens insupportables incapables de rédiger un texte introductif sans présupposer de vastes connaissances de la part du lecteur. Cet ouvrage, rédigé dans un style suranné, regorge de sous-entendus inexpliqués et de références obscures, ce qui en rend la lecture frustrante et difficile. On est très loin d'une approche du type de "l'histoire pour les nuls" ici, il s'agit plus d'un résumé pour connaisseurs que d'un texte introductif.

books.title: Marketing Today's Academic Library: A Bold New Approach to Communicating with Students
books.author: Mathews, Brian

books.title: The Summer of Love
books.author: Drechsler, Debbie
books.notes: I read "The Summer of Love" straight after the disturbing autobiographical "Daddy's Girl" by the same author, which features the same characters when they were younger. Whereas "Daddy's Girl" depicts the tragic abuse Lily had to suffer on the hands of her father, none of it is present in "The Summer of Love", which concentrates on the more classic foes of coming of age in suburban America. Sadly, it is also a road much traveled in contemporary graphic fiction, and Debbie Drechsler's slightly caricatural style does not match the finesse of other authors such as Craig Thomson or Alison Bechdel. What's more, the brownish-greenish color scheme used here is reminiscent of those blue-red 3D images when read without the appropriate colored glasses and are tiresome in the long run.

books.title: Daddy's Girl
books.author: Drechsler, Debbie
books.notes: This very powerful autobiography in comic form relates the childhood of the author and the sexual abuse she suffered from her father. The struggles of the child to reconcile her deeply wounded self with the "normality" of her sisters and school friends are very aptly related. This book is the stunning result of a very courageous introspective process, and serves as a disturbing remainder of the untold atrocities suffered by children who shared the author's fate. This being said, I am not a great fan of Debbie Drechsler graphic art and was therefore unable to immerse myself in the story as much as I had wanted. I also regretted the abrupt end of the book, the lack of a more adult take on the situation and a possible confrontation with the perpetrator.

books.title: The Art of Procrastination: A Guide to Effective Dawdling, Lollygagging and Postponing
books.author: Perry, John
books.notes: This is an amusing read, if only because all of its readers probably used reading it as an excuse to not doing anything more useful, and it's nice not to feel alone in such moments. Which is precisely the only reason why this book was written: to reassure procrastinators that they are not alone and that most of the time they still get things eventually done. That's nice, but I doubt that there remains a single procrastinator on this planet who is unaware that his plight is shared by a large population.

books.title: Building a Buzz: Libraries and Word-of-mouth Marketing
books.author: Barber, Peggy
books.notes: This book is meant as a marketing starting point for small libraries, filled with real-life examples and practical tips to provide inspiration. It may look simplistic, but actually addresses the core aspects of communication marketing in an efficient way, without insisting on the theoretical background.

books.title: Marketing Concepts for Libraries and Information Services
books.author: Saez, Eileen Elliott De
books.notes: This text is an excellent primer (or summary, depending on the reader's knowledge) on marketing strategy for academic or public libraries. The subject is adressed in a compact, practical manner, and is complemented with a step-by-step manual for preparing and implementing a marketing plan.[return]The bibliography mentions a few (ancient) basic textbooks as well as some research papers for further reading, but is overall insufficient for readers who might otherwise have used Elliott de Saéz's book as a starting point in marketing. Except maybe for the chapter on Internet marketing, the age of this book (10 years when this review was written) doesn't matter much, as most concepts are still current and remain well-presented.

books.title: The Signal and the Noise: Why So Many Predictions Fail — but Some Don't
books.author: Silver, Nate
books.notes: This is probably one of the best nonfiction books I've ever read. Predictions are everywhere in our lives: we choose mates, jobs, our clothes in the morning, a school for our children based on our possibly poorly informed, influenced yet usually overly confident forecasts. And of course, there are those who make a living out of predicting the weather or the evolution of the stock market (and then bet somebody else's money). Nate Silver very efficiently proves that nearly every prediction we make is flawed because we mistake noise for signal, dismiss low probabilities as "impossibilities" and tend to prefer listening to over-confident forecasters rather than cautious ones. It is a vital reality check: this book should be mandatory reading to every professional forecasters, especially economists and policy makers.[return]It is a very dense text, though. The theory is very well explained and expertly illustrated, but there remains an awful lot of it. I also had trouble with the arcane baseball terminology that is used repeatedly to illustrate key concepts. Whereas all other examples are nicely introduced to help the reader understand, a prior knowledge of baseball seems to be a prerequisite for this book... I didn't like that, and it cost the book its otherwise well-deserved fifth star!

books.title: Bite-Sized Marketing: Realistic Solutions for the Over-Worked Librarian
books.author: Dowd, Nancy
books.notes: This is a very practical, no-nonsense book that aims to provide libraries with tools to help them better promote their activities. Although it is clearly geared towards small public libraries, larger libraries can benefit from some of the insights provided by this book, particularly regarding word-of-mouth marketing.

books.title: Divine Vintage: Following the Wine Trail from Genesis to the Modern Age
books.author: Heskett, Randall
books.notes: Although certain religious groups insist on temperance and consider alcoholic drinks as sinful, wine is present throughout the Bible. From the intoxication of Lot by his incestuous daughters to the Last Supper, wine plays an important, generally positive, role. But what wine would Jesus drink? The authors of "Divine Vintage" have set out to answer that question, by exploring biblical quotations and reviewing the history of wine (and beer) in and around Palestine.[return][return]Sadly, what sounds like an interesting topic is watered down, so to speak, by a tiresome rambling style. The first chapters of the book are even less structured than the rest, thick with Biblical quotes and a jagged logical progression. The historical aspects of winemaking are more interesting, but are frustratingly short and imprecise, while the tasting notes that conclude the book will provide little information to readers that will unlikely get the opportunity to encounter wine coming from obscure israeli wineries.[return][return]This book has potential, with an interesting subject and written by two authors with an undisputed knowledge in theology and wine tasting. Unfortunately, one feels that the publisher utterly failed in his editorial duties: not only is the book written in an awkward and unequal style, but gross typos and inexactitudes have been left over: "vine" and "wine" are often mixed up, units jump from imperial to metric when they have not been entirely forgotten, even God's name is not consistently spelled YHWH, even though the authors lengthily insist on this at the beginning of the book. Coming from a renowned publisher like Palgrave, such amateurism is shocking.

books.title: Dan Gets a Minivan: Life at the Intersection of Dude and Dad
books.author: Zevin, Dan
books.notes: This hilarious series of anecdotes echo the feelings of every one of us who suddenly turned into full-time dads. Thankfully, all of us aren't stressed-out Brooklyn yuppies and were able to escape many of Dan Zevin's plights. Nevertheless, his stories still resonate with aspects of our own dude-dad-metamorphosis, which makes them even more painfully funny. Conveniently, the stories are light and short enough to be enjoyed despite the constant interruption of our own progeny...

books.title: Canadian History for Dummies
books.author: Ferguson, Will
books.notes: Ferguson's light, slightly sarcastic tone makes this book a perfect primer for Canadian history. I especially liked the way the multiple sociopolitical forces that shaped the country are outlined right from the start and very clearly designed throughout the text. I would have liked a few more pointers to extra reading material, though, as many events are quite rapidly covered. Also, more and better maps would definitely help, especially for readers unfamiliar with Canadian geography.

books.title: Stop Forgetting to Remember: The Autobiography of Walter Kurtz
books.author: Kuper, Peter
books.notes: Most North American graphic novels seem to fit in three categories: superhero nonsense (which I often find boring with the notable exception of the Watchmen), pubescent horror stories (boring *and* mildly repulsive) and artsy, covertly autobiographical coming-of-age novels. The latter are generally better drawn than the former two and usually make for more interesting, if depressing, reads. Stop Forgetting to Remember fits exactly in that category: comics author Walter Kurtz, about to become a father, reflects on his past life as a geeky, pot-smoking teenager. As usual, most stories gravitate on his romantic failures and the inevitable discovery of the fairer sex (or, rather, sexes in that case). Thankfully, the author's broody recollections are offset by his present-day life as a new father, offering a positive, future-oriented outcome. All in all, a mature, well illustrated, humorous and finally not too depressing story.

books.title: Snaps
books.author: Kraatz, Rebecca
books.notes: One day, author Rebecca Kraatz bought a photo album from the 1940s at a flea market in Victoria, British Columbia. She then imagined the story behind each photograph contained in the album, and the relationships that may have existed between the unknown persons they portrayed. The result is a beautiful, soulful and a bit surreal depiction of wartime life on Vancouver Island and the hardships of women left behind by the men fighting in Europe.

books.title: Y: The Last Man, Vol. 9: Motherland
books.author: Vaughan, Brian K.

books.title: Y: The Last Man, Vol. 10: Whys and Wherefores
books.author: Vaughan, Brian
books.notes: This volume marks the end of the "Last Man" series. All in all, I enjoyed reading it but I never quite got into the story. I think the idea itself is brilliant, and the first episodes really did it justice, but then since volume 2, the story quickly lost its pace and became too convoluted. I also became quickly annoyed by the constant adolescent and phallocratic gallows humor. The future envisioned by Vaughan and Guerra might be what would become of our world if all the men would die, but only if all women were indeed as fantasized by pubescent boys. Fortunately, they aren't.

books.title: Y: The Last Man Vol. 8: Kimono Dragons
books.author: Vaughan, Brian K.

books.title: Y: The Last Man, Vol. 7: Paper Dolls
books.author: Vaughan, Brian K.

books.title: Y: The Last Man, Volume 6: Girl on Girl
books.author: Vaughan, Brian K.

books.title: Y: The Last Man, Vol. 4: Safeword
books.author: Vaughan, Brian K.

books.title: Y: The Last Man, Vol. 5: Ring of Truth
books.author: Vaughan, Brian K.

books.title: Y: The Last Man, Vol. 2: Cycles
books.author: Vaughan, Brian K.

books.title: Y: The Last Man, Vol. 3: One Small Step
books.author: Vaughan, Brian K.

books.title: Y: The Last Man, Vol. 1: Unmanned
books.author: Vaughan, Brian K.

books.title: Jerusalem: Chronicles from the Holy City
books.author: Delisle, Guy

books.title: For Matrimonial Purposes
books.author: Daswani, Kavita
books.notes: This book ambitions to blend "The devil wears Prada" with "A suitable boy" but fails to enchant on both counts. The passivity of the heroine and her futile lifestyle make her character bland and unlikable. Boring.

books.title: La Ville absente
books.author: Piglia, Ricardo
books.notes: Junior le reporter reçoit un beau jour un tuyau, l'enjoignant de se soustraire à la surveillance constante du gouvernement pour aller voir un certain Fuyita. Celui-ci est gardien de musée et semble affecté à la surveillance de la Machine, une étrange construction mi-femme mi-automate, dont le but premier était de traduire les récits d'une langue à l'autre avant que l'on ne remarque qu'elle modifiait imperceptiblement la trame des histoires que l'on lui a confiées. La piste de Junior se brouille rapidement, tout comme le fil du récit, emmêlé dans les innombrables histoires fabriquées par la Machine, où réapparaissent certains personnages et où tout sens du réel finit par se dissoudre. Là où Junior a trouvé le courage de continuer son enquête, j'ai moi-même perdu patience dans l'univers de plus en plus absurde du récit, mêlant éléments historiques et pur onirisme. Sans doute les connaisseurs de littérature sud-américaine apprécieront les allusions réparties à travers le récit, les autres en seront rapidement découragés...

books.title: The Man in the Wooden Hat
books.author: Gardam, Jane
books.notes: This companion novel to "Old Filth" relates the couple's marriage from the spouse's point of view: here, the story is told by Betty, Filth's wife. While the text still vibrates from Gardam's extraordinary prose and remains throughly enjoyable, I was nevertheless a little bit disappointed and found Betty less interesting than her husband.

books.title: Weight Loss
books.author: Chatterjee, Upamanyu
books.notes: Weight Loss is the coming of age story of a slightly overweight boy with depressingly strange sexual proclivities. The novel concentrates mainly on the latter, resulting in a fetid mix of highly disturbing descriptions of the characters' obsessions. Definitely not my cup of tea, I gave up after the first 140 pages.

books.title: Three Great Novels: Let it Bleed / Black & Blue / The Hanging Garden
books.author: Rankin, Ian

books.title: Wallpaper* City Guide Edinburgh (Wallpaper City Guides)
books.author: Magazine, Editors of Wallpaper

books.title: Quiet: The Power of Introverts in a World That Can't Stop Talking
books.author: Cain, Susan
