books.title: Les trois piliers: le guide de la prévoyance active
books.author: Demeulemeester, Joy

books.title: Self Help
books.author: Docx, Edward
books.notes: Torn between St. Petersburg, London, Paris and New York, as well as their own personal crises, the members of the Glover family are suddenly brought together by the death of one of them. This event acts as a detonator for each character to come to terms with his or her problems. Couples are broken, flats burgled, and pianos shattered. And, slowly, lips are opened and secrets come to light...[return][return]This is not an easy book to read, it is dense and intricately constructed, yet very powerful. This is not a page-turner because it is the kind of book that requires pauses to think about the implications of what one has just read (and also to reflect on the blissful simplicity of one's own life). Docx's exploration of the intricacies of a dysfunctional family is masterful and his disenchanted rants against contract publishing and the "bullshitness" of modern life in general are a pleasure to read. This book is a journey, not easy, but rewarding.

books.title: Tubes : Behind the scenes at the Internet
books.author: Blum, Andrew

books.title: Organizing Knowledge: An Introduction to Managing Access to Information
books.author: Rowley, J. E.

books.title: Introduction to Modern Information Retrieval, Third Edition
books.author: Chowdhury, G.G.

books.title: Sex, Bombs and Burgers: How War, Porn and Fast Food Created Technology as We Know It
books.author: Nowak, Peter
books.notes: Nowak's book is a treasure trove of interesting miscellanea about the sometimes surprising origins of everyday items. Sadly, the fascinating stories are mixed with a very disturbing technocratic evangelism: gadgets promising a "clean" war in Irak are never questioned, and the criticism against genetically-modified crops is dismissed as a typical example of Europe's failure to embrace progress. Also unsettling to the gourmet reader is the unadulterated praise for the McDonaldization of food: in what universe is a machine-made concoction of pre-processed ingredients cooked in less than a minute by a blast of microwave-heated air called a "perfect pizza"?

books.title: Blink: The Power of Thinking Without Thinking
books.author: Gladwell, Malcolm
books.notes: This book offers very interesting insights into the way our intuition work, and powerfully underlines its strengths and weaknesses. Gladwell is truly a captivating storyteller, even though all the examples he uses to illustrate his point are not always used up to their full potential and some are even downright anecdotal.

books.title: On Guerrilla Gardening
books.author: Reynolds, Richard
books.notes: This book is a good primer on the concept of guerrilla gardening, with interesting anecdotes and historical background to boot. Sadly, it is very sparingly illustrated and somewhat lengthy while remaining superficial, thus missing its mark a little: too drab for newbies yet too superficial for wannabes...

books.title: The Expert Library: Staffing, Sustaining, and Advancing The Academic Library in The 21st Century
books.author: Walter, Scott

books.title: The Man Who Would Be King & Other Stories (Wordsworth Classics)
books.author: Kipling, Rudyard

books.title: L'homme qui voulait être heureux
books.author: Gounelle, Laurent
books.notes: Ce livre de self-help maladroitement romancé peut se résumer en une phrase: aide-toi et le ciel t'aidera. C'est pompier, franchouillard et, deux ans après "Mange, prie, aime" d'Elisabeth Gilbert, on ne peut plus nous faire le coup du sage balinais ascétique-mais-qui-sait-quand-même-comment-fonctionne-une-banque-en-France.

books.title: La typographie suisse : Du Bauhaus à Paris
books.author: Chatelain, Roger
books.notes: Le sujet est intéressant, malheureusement le ton empesé de l'auteur rend la lecture de cet ouvrage particulièrement ennuyeuse... Rares sont les concepts qui sont expliqués au néophyte, les exemples sont peu nombreux et mal illustrés. Il ne s'agit pas du tout d'une introduction à la typographie, mais plutôt d'une série de biographies très résumées.

books.title: Major Pettigrew's Last Stand: A Novel
books.author: Simonson, Helen
books.notes: The sudden death of his brother ripples through Major Pettigrew's well organized life. But the constant attacks inflicted upon his distinguished morale and upbringing by the vulgarities of his family and neighbors amount to nothing agains the disturbance caused by his quite unexpected affection for the pakistani village shop lady...[return][return]This story might be a bit caricatural in its depiction of racist prejudice, its humor and lightness makes it nevertheless a quite enjoyable read. I found the character of the Major especially likable.

books.title: Eat, Pray, Love: One Woman's Search for Everything Across Italy, India and Indonesia
books.author: Gilbert, Elizabeth

books.title: Speaking American: A History of English in the United States
books.author: Bailey, Richard W.
books.notes: Don't expect a Bill Bryson style list of vocabulary trivia here:  "Speaking American" is a rather dull and scholarly rambling about the evolution of the English language spoken in America from the first immigrants to the 21st century. Not uninteresting, but sadly not very entertaining.

books.title: River of Smoke
books.author: Ghosh, Amitav
books.notes: While still a huge fan of Amitav Ghosh, I must admit that I had trouble reading through "River of Smoke" which I felt was missing the impetus of "Sea of Poppies". Its intricate web of stories can sometimes be hard to follow, and the otherwise interesting vocabulary richness tends to burden the reading with added confusion when used with too much profusion.[return]Fortunately, the last part of the book, set in Canton at the onset of the Opium Wars, is a another fine example of Ghosh's mastery in gripping historical fiction.

books.title: An Introduction To Staff Development In Academic Libraries
books.author: Connor, Elizabeth

books.title: Cradle to Cradle: Remaking the Way We Make Things
books.author: Braungart, Michael

books.title: Made to Break: Technology and Obsolescence in America
books.author: Slade, Giles
books.notes: This book sheds light into the practice of planned obsolescence, one that is as crucial to a consumerist economy as advertisement and private credit, although sadly less known. Unfortunately, the most interesting parts of Slade's story are diluted with bits and pieces of the history of technology that do not bring much to the main subject.

books.title: Wallpaper* City Guide Amsterdam 2012 (Wallpaper City Guides)
books.author: Magazine, Editors of Wallpaper

books.title: Lean Library Management: Eleven Strategies for Reducing Costs and Improving Services
books.author: Huber, John
books.notes: This is an excellent, no-nonsense and practical book that should be on every library's shelves. John Huber is a consulting veteran coming from the manufacturing industry and striving to apply the concepts of lean manufacturing (aka the Toyota model) to the world of libraries. His common sense approach to practical service delivery problems faced by libraries allows him to find practical and non-orthodox solutions that would have been obvious to the library employees had they not been too focussed on their problems to notice. He advocates novel ways to measure library performance, in analogy to the manufacturing industry, and to think above the usual departmental barriers. Huber should be mandatory reading for every librarian, period.

books.title: Mistakes in Academic Library Management: Grievous Errors and How to Avoid Them
books.author: Fritts, Jack E., Jr.
books.notes: This is a very pragmatic collection of short essays about several aspects of management and leadership applied to academic libraries (in the US): change management (mostly), project management, knowledge management, assessment, etc. The essays are of variable quality, but they all contain good leads to further in-depth references. A good starting point.

books.title: The Belbin Guide to Succeeding at Work
books.author: Associates, Belbin
books.notes: This very short book is intended as a guide to use Belbin's Team Roles theory to help in planned career changes. A short explanation of each Team Role is followed by general advice on how to determine the organisational culture of a prospective employer and adapt in consequence. The result is a very basic text that offers no groundbreaking advice but may help persons seeking a career change to ask themselves the correct questions and help them reorient themselves.

books.title: Team Roles at Work
books.author: Belbin, Meredith R
books.notes: This book is much more useful and interesting than the original text Belbin wrote on his Team Roles theory (Management Teams: Why they succeed or fail). Departing from the social science mumbo-jumbo, it focuses on the practical applications of the theory in a working environment. Many of what Belbin states is still frightfully undocumented (especially his ramblings on the history of leadership) but the practical aspects seem sound.

books.title: Management Teams: Why they succeed or fail
books.author: Belbin, R Meredith
books.notes: Belbin's "Team roles" model may be a good management tool, but this book does nothing to encourage its usage. This is the third edition of the first book Belbin apparently wrote on the subject, therefore it focuses more on his research process than on the actual results. Unfortunately, it is neither informative nor entertaining: experiments follow each other in what seems like a hastened a posteriori justification, the case studies are colourless and the "indubitable proofs" Belbin offers to his theory turn out to be nothing but half-baked empirical descriptions. The only objective evidence would have been the actual numbered results of his experiments, but these are carefully hidden in two undocumented, barely readable figures (the only two figures in the whole book)! Readers with a rational mind will have trouble believing anything Belbin is arguing. I was not impressed. Reading this book is a waste of time.

books.title: The Challenge of Library Management: Leading With Emotional Engagement
books.author: vanDuinkerken, Wyoma
books.notes: This concise and easy-to-read book presents many tools and concepts that can be useful when managing change in libraries. As the subtitle implies, it concentrates on the human factor and advocates careful planning and empowerment strategies to efficiently involve staff in the change process. I missed some more advice on project management and more information on assessment tools.

books.title: The New Professionals Handbook: Your Guide to Information Services Management
books.author: Corrall, Sheila

books.title: Leadership Basics for Librarians and Information Professionals
books.author: Evans, Edward G.
books.notes: This book is a good primer on leadership applied to the library world. It presents the main concepts of management science and organizational behavior in a clear and comprehensive way, while suggesting external references to go further. It ends with a list of common problems encountered by library managers, with pointers on how to solve them, and a recap-style list of the crucial success factors.

books.title: Managing Change: A How-to-Do-It Manual for Libraries
books.author: Curzon, Susan Carol
books.notes: This very basic book is written in the form of a check list, reviewing all steps necessary to efficiently handle change. It can be a good resource for beginners in a management position or as a check list to make sure nothing was left out in an important project.

books.title: It is not a piece of cake
books.author: Peña, Nancy

books.title: Corner Shop
books.author: Farooki, Roopa
books.notes: Farooki's book is hard to define: part chick-lit, part coming-of-age story, mixing football, teenage romance and complicated adult relationships... Although the main characters have Bangladeshi roots, the Asian influence plays almost no role in the novel. A pinch of exotism is brought by France instead, where the author apparently lives, with all the usual annoying clichés and failed affectation (useless, misspelled French words). I liked the way the story is organized in the first part of the book, with appropriately timed flashbacks that progressively reveal relevant elements of the characters past to bring perspective to the current events. Sadly, the second part is much less interestingly constructed and even ends up quite abruptly.[return]Despite these shortcomings, "Corner Shop" is a nice and original story, with generally likable characters.

books.title: Man with a Pan
books.author: Donohue, John
books.notes: That my wife brought this book back from her latest trip as a gift for me meant a lot for me, as a little recognition certainly means a lot to the thousands of dads out there who regularly cook for their families. This witty anthology goes beyond the classic "men who cook" (either chefs or fair-weather dads whose sole contribution is lighting up the BBQ on Sunday) and plunges right into the flour-covered lives of men who shop for groceries, plan dinners, chop veggies and tell their children how to hold a colander.[return][return]That we are not alone out there is already a refreshing thought, but this book goes much farther by being utterly entertaining and informative. Each invited author contributes a few of their key cookbooks and, of course, unveil some of their prized recipes. Even though some stories tend to corroborate the usual cliché of "stunt-cooking" men with large amounts of virile meat and grunted fishing tales, most are more sensible and together give a fairly broad overview of the many styles of cooking. Utterly delicious.

books.title: Junk Love
books.author: Chaemin
books.notes: La dessinatrice coréenne Chaemin nous livre dans "Junk Love" l'histoire d'un couple qui n'en est pas vraiment un. La relation de Ho-gyeong et Min-gyu est erratique et sans avenir, pourtant chaque repas partagé semble les unir plus qu'ils ne le souhaiteraient. Le fil du récit se répartit en plusieurs épisodes de lignes temporelles parallèles, reliés par la nourriture consommée ce jour-là. Les constants flashbacks ainsi créés permettent d'explorer de façon originale les nombreux non-dits de la relation entre les deux protagonistes.

books.title: La librairie des ombres
books.author: Birkegaard, Mikkel
books.notes: La mort mystérieuse de son père, libraire à Copenhague, entraîne Jon dans les méandres d'une étrange organisation qui semble tirer son pouvoir des vieux livres...[return][return]Ce roman est distrayant, mais manque un peu d'originalité et de cohérence.

books.title: Time to Eat the Dog: The Real Guide to Sustainable Living
books.author: Vale, Robert

books.title: Le canapé de Beria
books.author: Quétel, Claude
books.notes: Cet ouvrage réunit quelques souvenirs de Claude Quétel, historien et ancien directeur scientifique du Mémorial de Caen, lorsqu'il sillonnait la planète à la recherche d'objets pour son musée. Comment acquiert-on un "orgue de Staline"? Où se trouvent les premières bombes atomiques américaines? Vous le saurez en lisant ce récit étonnant.

books.title: Sommeil
books.author: Murakami, Haruki
books.notes: Une jeune mère de famille perd soudain le sommeil. Loin de l'épuiser, ces étranges insomnies réveillent en elle de nouveaux désirs. Cette magnifique et déroutante nouvelle de Murakami est superbement illustrée par Kat Menschik.

books.title: Solo
books.author: Dasgupta, Rana
books.notes: In a dilapidated building in Sofia, a blind old man is reflecting on his past life. This superbly narrated story of his dreams, loves, downfall and piecing together echoes the fate of his country through its struggle for independence, two world wars, communism and hangover capitalism. A string of satellite stories very cleverly completes the picture. This book is absolutely brillant and a delight to read.

books.title: Der andere Hotelführer: Umweltfreundlich logieren in der Schweiz
books.author: Reichen, Sabine
books.notes: Ce guide présente une sélection d'hôtels de toutes catégories, du dortoir alpin au quatre-étoiles, mais dont le point commun est un souci de développement durable "intelligent". Loin du greenwashing à la mode dans les grands groupes hôteliers, les établissements présents dans ce guide ont tous fait un geste simple en faveur de l'environnement. En cuisine, par exemple, la plupart ne jure que par des produits locaux ou bio, certains tendent même à l'autarcie alimentaire, mais sans renoncer à une gastronomie de qualité. Tous sont accessibles en transports publics et à proximité de loisirs variés et doux pour l'environnement (marche, ski de fond, musées, etc.).[return][return]Le guide présente l'historique de chaque établissement et la démarche de développement durable qui l'anime. Il indique également quels hôtels sont adaptés aux vacances en famille, et quelle est la meilleure saison pour s'y rendre. Un très bon point de départ pour les prochaines vacances en Suisse![return][return]Seul point négatif: ce guide n'est actuellement disponible qu'en allemand...

books.title: Spirale
books.author: Ito, Junji
books.notes: Kirié est lycéenne dans la petite ville de Kurozu. Un soir, en allant à la rencontre de son petit ami, elle remarque d'étranges tourbillons. Dans une allée déserte, un homme regarde fixement un coquillage. Bientôt, les événements étranges se multiplieront et la tranquille petite ville sombrera dans le chaos sous l'emprise de la terrifiante spirale...[return][return]"Spirale" est un mélange de poésie et d'horreur qui fait froid dans le dos. Plus encore que les quelques pages particulièrement effrayantes de l'ouvrage, c'est leur contraste avec la douceur des traits de l'héroïne qui est particulièrement déstabilisant. N'étant personnellement pas amateur de "gore", je n'ai pas vraiment aimé ce livre, mais je reconnais l'excellence du dessin et la subtilité du scénario.

books.title: Le mec de la tombe d'à côté
books.author: Mazetti, Katarina
books.notes: Désirée est bibliothécaire dans une petite ville. Jeune veuve, elle se rend régulièrement sur la tombe de son mari. Ces instants seraient parfaits pour s'apitoyer tranquillement sur son sort... s'il n'y avait pas ce type agaçant sur la tombe d'à côté.[return][return]Cette histoire est originale et sympathique, joliment écrite en présentant en alternance le point de vue des deux protagonistes. Cependant, le sujet reste léger et on s'en lasse assez vite. Divertissant.

books.title: Tierra del Fuego
books.author: Coloane, Francisco
books.notes: Les nouvelles de Francisco Coloane sont de celles qui éveillent immédiatement un besoin urgent de voir du pays, partir au bout du monde tâter de la beauté sauvage de la Terre de Feu et y rencontrer l'espace d'un récit de sombres personnages aux rêves meurtris mais à l'humanité intacte...

books.title: Allmen et les libellules
books.author: Suter, Martin
books.notes: Les dettes s'accumulent sur Johann Friedrich von Allmen, collectioneur d'oeuvres d'art et esthète oisif préoccupé par la disparition pourtant prévisible de sa fortune. Malgré sa situation fâcheuse, von Allmen n'envisage pas une seconde de réduire son train de vie. Il se résout donc à vendre un à un les précieux joyaux de sa collection... ou de celle des autres.[return][return]Le personnage de von Allmen est caractéristique des héros de Martin Suter: un parasite heureux et déraisonnable, attachant malgré son cynisme naïf. Ce premier volume d'une série "d'enquêtes" menées par von Allmen se lit d'une seule traite et laisse présager le meilleur.[return][return]Seule ombre au tableau, la traduction en français ignore comme toujours superbement les particularités linguistiques romandes, qu'il aurait été élégant d'employer pour traduire un auteur Suisse-Alémanique. Et la mention du "lac de Neuenburg" laisse songeur sur les efforts de documentation du traducteur...

books.title: Oracle Night
books.author: Auster, Paul
books.notes: This is a dense story, with many ramifications, stories nested within the story and metaphysical coincidences. Thanks to Auster's precise writing and impeccable storytelling, the reader never feels lost in the multiple plots. Reading Oracle Night is quite like wandering the rooms of a museum: they are arranged in a precise, chronological order, yet multiple doors allow visitors to momentarily get back in time or immerge in a different genre before returning to the main exhibit. This meandering must be how a writer feels when he is obsessed with a story, and Auster manages to bring this feeling to his readers in a remarkable way.

books.title: The Anger of Aubergines
books.author: Sharma, Bulbul
books.notes: 12 delectable short stories about the daily lives of women, told through the food they cook, share, love and crave for. Food is intricately linked with their daily lives. It is a gift they offer or receive, and an indispensable element of power over the numerous men who always try to control them...[return]Each story is concluded by a handful of simple yet mouth-watering recipes that make you want to drop everything and try them out.

books.title: Dictionnaire impertinent de la Suisse : De A comme Aar à Z comme Zwingli
books.author: Mettan, Guy
books.notes: Une jolie collection de bons mots amusants sur la Suisse et ses institutions. La qualité des entrées est très variable et certaines omissions sont étranges, mais dans l'ensemble ce "Dictionnaire" est une lecture agréable, voire instructive, aussi bien pour les Suisses que pour les étrangers du dehors.

books.title: Le diable de Milan
books.author: Suter, Martin
books.notes: Fuyant un mari violent, Sonia part travailler dans un grand hôtel des Grisons. L'établissement a récemment été rénové à grand frais par sa jeune propriétaire, qui pourtant ne semble pas préoccupée par la rentabilité de son établissement. Ni par une série de mauvaises blagues qui rappellent une ancienne légende alpine...[return][return]Dans ce thriller alpin très bien construit, Martin Suter démontre une fois de plus son talent de scénariste.

books.title: Solar
books.author: McEwan, Ian
books.notes: Professor Michael Beard is a Nobel prize-winning physicist whose works on artificial photosynthesis are set to save the world from global warming. Yet at the same time, Professor Beard is an immature and selfish misanthropist with a knack for turning every situation to his personal advantage. Fraud or genius, Professor Beard is a modern Dr. Jekyll in a well-written satire of the academic world that reminded me of David Lodge's early novels.

books.title: Geek Nation: How Indian Science Is Taking Over the World
books.author: Saini, Angela
books.notes: Geek nation is an interesting account about the current status of education, science and government modernization in India. Written in a pleasant tone and peppered with amusing anecdotes, it offers some insights about why certain innovations were due to happen in India of all places.

books.title: La Suisse mode d'emploi histoire, politique, économie, droit
books.author: Kucholl, Vincent

books.title: Happiness™
books.author: Ferguson, Will
books.notes: If anyone wrote a self-help book that actually worked, we'd all be in trouble". This comment by a book publicist allegedly prompted Will Ferguson to write Happiness™, a satire of the self-help industry and of publishing in general. Happiness™ is the story of such a book, one that works so well that it instantly makes all its readers happy... and thus brings the whole Western economy to screeching halt, said economy being notoriously entirely dependent on a constant supply of unsatiated desires. The result is a thoroughly enjoyable read, full of dark humor and inconvenient truths about the publishing industry, and a testament to what makes life enjoyable: guilty pleasures, unhealthy food and unrequited yearning.

books.title: Le cuisinier
books.author: Suter, Martin
books.notes: Maravan, un jeune réfugié tamoul vivant à Zurich, met ses talents culinaires au service d'un marché bien spécifique: il cuisine à domicile des repas aphrodisiaques. Son entreprise est florissante et séduit de plus en plus de clients, jusqu'au jour où il découvre un lien dérangeant entre l'un d'entre eux et la situation préoccupante de son pays d'origine...[return][return]Un sujet original et une intrigue bien construite ont fait le succès des romans de Martin Suter. On retrouve ces mêmes ingrédients dans "le cuisiner", même si certaines situations restent peu vraisemblables et le dénouement de l'histoire se révèle au fond assez banal. La traduction française est de meilleure facture que celle des premiers Suter, même s'il reste hélas évident que le traducteur n'est pas familier avec le paysage linguistique helvétique.

books.title: The Harappa Files
books.author: Banerjee, Sarnath
books.notes: The Harappa Files is a hodge-podge of short vignettes depicting everyday life in modern India, bits of history, nostalgia and unlikely contradictions. A good knowledge of Indian culture is therefore necessary to fully appreciate this collection of stories. For this reason, I enjoyed the Files less than the other Banerjee graphic novels. Still, most stories are enjoyable even to the outsider, and the author's ability to pinpoint little details of human behavior is remarkable.

books.title: Cracking the TOEFL IBT with Audio CD, 2009 Edition (College Test Preparation)
books.author: Review, Princeton
books.notes: The TOEFL actually being more about cracking very specific tasks than testing language ability, it always pays to come to the test well prepared. This book provides a good insight in the ways the bizarre minds of the TOEFL experts work and how to answer what they want to hear. It contains a summary of the four parts of the test, provides examples and methods to prepare for it. Too bad it doesn't come with a CD-ROM containing actual practice questions (there's only an audio CD included). I would recommend pairing it with other books containing good practice material, such as the Longman TOEFL preparation CD-ROM by Deborah Phillips.

books.title: Wanderungen zu historischen Berghotels: 22 Touren auf den Spuren alpiner Pioniere
books.author: Ihle, Jochen

books.title: Die schönsten Spaziergänge der Schweiz unterwegs mit dem Schweizer Heimatschutz en route avec Patrimoine suisse
On Food and Cooking: The Science and Lore of the Kitchen
books.author: McGee, Harold

books.title: The Hundred-Foot Journey: A Novel
books.author: Morais, Richard C
books.notes: This is the story of Hassan, an Indian cook, recently immigrated in France, and his rapid ascension of the social chain to become the first French cook of foreign origin to receive a 3-star rating in the Guide Michelin. The "hundred foot journey" refers to the distance separating his father's curry house from a French haute cuisine restaurant, where Hassan starts his apprenticeship, and a metaphor of the social and racial divide he had to cross.[return][return]I found the general idea interesting and was immediately appealed by the settings: a book about India, immigration and food, what could possibly get wrong? Well, a lot, as it appears. I ended up greatly disappointed. I couldn't help but feel that by peppering his tale with bits of Urdu, French and culinary details, Morais desperately tried to hide the fact that he was neither Indian, nor French, nor a cook. The result is an impossible medley of heavy clichés and grammatical mistakes (for the French bits at least) that do more harm than good to the story.[return][return]Finally, Morais' idealization of French "haute cuisine" as the ultimate cooking nirvana definitely struck a wrong cord in me, who never had any patience with all this haughty nonsense...

books.title: An Atlas of Impossible Longing: A Novel
books.author: Roy, Anuradha
books.notes: In this beautiful and melancholic story, we follow several generations of a Bengali family and their intertwining lives. Whoever they are, every character secretly pines for something or someone, but never being able to sever the strong bonds of family and tradition, their lives go on and their longings remain desperately impossible...[return]This novel is delicately written and lively with colorful characters. Stories of impossible love are always sad, but Anuradha Roy's beautiful narration uncovers the hidden joy of hope in the most desperate situations.

books.title: Spousonomics: Or How to Maximise Returns on the Biggest Investment of Your Life
books.author: Szuchman, Paula
books.notes: As with the majority of self-help books, Spousonomics is mainly about the systematization of common sense. But unlike other self-help books, it is quite open about that systematization, and that's what makes it stand out. Its authors, both economists and (apparently happily) married women, explain how to apply some basic economics methods to common coupledom problems. The result is not terribly interesting, but fun to read nevertheless.

books.title: Little Bee: A Novel
books.author: Cleave, Chris
books.notes: Little Bee is the sad story of the seemingly endless suffering of refugees, but told in a tender, humorous and original way. The language is beautiful, the main characters eminently human and likable, and Chris Cleave's gentle tone is perfect to drive home the hard underlying facts of his story.

books.title: A Case of Exploding Mangoes
books.author: Hanif, Mohammed
books.notes: What exactly caused the aircraft carrying Pakistan's president Zia-ul-Haq, his top brass and the US ambassador to crash in 1988? Nobody knows. Maybe Mohammed Hanif is right, and this book unveils the mystery. Or maybe it's just a story. But it's a great story, a journey through the contradictions of a crumbling military dictatorship through the eyes of an impertinent young soldier, a fun and informative look at central Asia at the end of the Cold War, and an impeccable thriller that will not let itself be put down until the end.

books.title: The Dewey Decimal System: A Novel (Akashic Urban Surreal Series)
books.author: Larson, Nathan
books.notes: In a post-apocalyptic New York, left half-empty and under the rule of thugs and corrupt officials after an unprecedented series of terrorist attacks, lives a man that doesn't remember his name. Known as Dewey Decimal because he lives in the deserted New York Public Library, he makes a living as a mercenary. His last job, eliminating a union leader, seemed simple enough at first...[return][return]I very much enjoyed this story. Larson's tough-talking, obsessive-compulsive antihero takes an original go at the first-person detective story. The fast-paced action makes this book very hard to put down. I hope there will be a sequel.

books.title: Speak to Our Desires
books.author: Clough, Brenda W.
books.notes: When a young and beautiful model hires him to find her missing mother, the life of detective Tim Coates is about to change forever. Set in the late 1960s, and deliberately trying for the particular atmosphere of the detective story à la Chandler, the setting for this book promised great fun. Sadly, the story fails to grab the reader's attention, somewhat concentrating on irrelevant details and neglecting to exploit the good plot ideas. The love story between the main characters is pathetically unlikely, the descriptions seem incoherent with the era in which the action is supposed to unfold and the plot's ending, while certainly unexpected, doesn't really make sense with the rest of the story.

books.title: Superfreakonomics
books.author: Levitt, Steven D.
books.notes: Banking on the success of their previous book, Levitt and Dubner deliver their new handful of unorthodox theories about just anything provided it's a bit raucous so as to draw in the crowds (a new helping of hooker's business model anyone?). Not all stories are created equal: I enjoyed the ingenuity of the banking activity-based terrorist detector scheme, for example, but got increasingly worried as I read the chapter on global warming. While the tone is one of noncommittal objectiveness in the previous chapters, the authors grow positively ecstatic about the Dr. Frankenstein's geoengineering schemes proposed by Nathan Myhrvold... Could this discrepancy reveal a not-so-subtle hidden agenda?[return]In any case, it is still an entertaining read, although what made the first Freakonomics original is starting to wear off.

books.title: Freakonomics
books.author: Dubner, Stephen J.
books.notes: Levitt's renegade use of the typical tools of economics (basically stats and some interpretation peppered with common sense) addresses baroque problems such as the business model of pimps or the impact of a child's name on its school grades. Some home-brewed theories are also thrown in for good measure, such as the impact of legalized abortion on crime rates. An entertaining read, if one remembers not to take the author's word on everything he says...

books.title: Aerotropolis: The Way We'll Live Next
books.author: Kasarda, John D.
books.notes: If anything, this book is a good overview of the globalized economy in 2010. Whether we like it or not, our world has grown utterly dependent on air freight and travel, with vast quantities of passengers and goods revolving around the urban planning nightmares we usually call 'airports'. Kasarda's theory is that we should stop considering the airport as an ugly but necessary extension to a city and start seeing the airport as the de facto city centre.[return]The book is well-written, but lacks a clear logic between the chapters. Which are often too long and end up a bit boring. After the first chapters, I almost dismissed the book as a tarmac-happy, idealized vision of a boundless global economy, with no second thoughts about environmental or social costs. Thankfully, the second half of the book do address these issues, with some interesting insights on why calculating the carbon footprint of air travel isn't as easy as one might think.[return]Still, I always hated airports and probably always will do. For some reason, Kasarda's "idyllic" vision of a gigantic airport surrounded by a Sim City-like mix of commercial and residential areas, where shopping malls and golf courses supposedly suffice in making the inhabitants of such an artificial landscape feel at home, fails to resonate with me... I live 50km away from the nearest airport and I'm very happy about it.

books.title: Danse, danse, danse
books.author: Murakami, Haruki
books.notes: On retrouve dans ce roman le héros anonyme de la Course au Mouton Sauvage, embarqué dans une nouvelle aventure à cheval entre rêve éveillé et réalité. A lire pour se replonger avec délices dans le monde mélancolique des années 1980, des Toyota Corolla et des adolescentes qui écoutent Boy George sur leur Walkman. A lire également pour le talent tout particulier de Murakami à mêler hyperréalisme et fantastique, le tout saupoudré de références musicales aussi éclectiques que le monde dans lequel se meuvent ses personnages...

books.title: Eating Animals
books.author: Foer, Jonathan Safran
books.notes: This is a very interesting book for anyone not familiar with factory farming as it is perpetrated in North America. For my part, I wasn't aware of the magnitude of the situation, and was thus horrified to learn that such a minime proportion of meat produced in the US comes from sensible husbandry. Still, the book remains very US-centric and it would be interesting to know about the situation in other parts of the world. In Switzerland where I live, for example, it is relatively easy to find top-quality, locally and familiy produced meat, if you are ready to shell out a little bit more than for supermarket fare. And thus I have no problems being a "selective omnivore", eating mostly vegetarian food and occasionnaly indulging in a good piece of meat.[return][return]To get back to the US situation, the conclusion I'm personnaly drawing after reading JSF's book is that the real problem is that there is virtually no legislation to control meat production, and that is extremely worrisome. The "solution" to this problem is probably not a handful of well-educated people going vegetarian, but a real political uprising to demand stricter governement control. And also a decrease in the consumption of cheap meat by the population at large, but this book will probably fail to reach the people most in need of education on these matters. One good thing about this book is that it at least gets people talking. Just look at the reviews on LT...

books.title: L'Année du mensonge
books.author: Guelassimov, Andreï
books.notes: Dans la gabegie du Moscou post-communiste, chacun tente de tirer son épingle du jeu sans trop s'encombrer de principes moraux. Mikhail s'en sort plutôt bien: il est (bien) payé pour apprendre au jeune Sergueï à boire et courir les filles. C'était sans compter sur le fait que Sergueï est loin d'être aussi renfermé et coupé du monde que son père voudrait bien le croire... Entre jeu de pouvoir, argent et grosses voitures, le monde de Guelassimov ressemble furieusement à celui d'Andreï Kourkov ("Le pingouin"): les caïds ont le coeur tendre, les criminels philosophent et les filles ont de la répartie à revendre.

books.title: The Terrible Privacy of Maxwell Sim
books.author: Coe, Jonathan
books.notes: When she finally divorced him, Maxwell Sim's wife left him a parting gift: a non-refundable Qantas ticket. A nudge to get him to finally visit his estranged father, who has emigrated to Australia. Barely recovering from clinical depression, Max does visit his father and thus starts the long journey through the past of various characters that will ultimately lead him to his father's secret. And to an abrupt, quite unexpected end...[return]The story is written in that excellent dark british humor that manages to turn the private life of a depressed toothbrush salesman into a gripping story. David Lodge comes to mind. Brilliant!

books.title: Ghost World
books.author: Clowes, Daniel
books.notes: This is a good example of the new-era of american graphic novels: away from the superhero stereotypes, realistic, cynical and well-drawn. But the storyline is a bit weak, and the two main characters, two pre-college best friends facing the slap of adulthood, are hard to relate to.

books.title: The Textile Planet
books.author: Lange, Sue
books.notes: The Textile Planet is as story with an interesting setting and a good start idea, but sadly suffers from its rather inconsistent writing. Some parts are packed with action and are good reads, but they are separated by lengthy pseudo-philosophical ramblings and descriptive passages that strongly contrast in style with the rest of the story. I wanted to know the end of the story and so kept on reading, but it wasn't a page-turner.

books.title: Traffic: Why we drive the way we do (and what it says about us)
books.author: Vanderbilt, Tom
books.notes: This is a surprisingly fascinating book, even (especially?) for car sceptics like me, shedding light on the many little-known facts that make traffic engineering such a complex matter. Exploring subjects such as congestion physics, group behavior, statistics, safety measures, traffic calming, culture biases and disturbingly adequate analogies with insect societies, Tom Vanderbilt gives a very thorough picture of the many counterintuitive facts about traffic. Reading this book won't help you avoid traffic jams, but at least you'll know how they work!

books.title: Les manipulateurs sont parmi nous : Qui sont-ils ? Comment s'en protéger ?
books.author: Nazare-Aga, Isabelle
books.notes: Ce livre aborde un sujet intéressant et peu souvent traité, celui des manipulateurs conscients et inconscients qui figurent dans notre entourage. De nombreux exemples (parfois caricaturaux) illustrent bien les différentes facettes de ces personnages qui sont souvent à l'origine de conflits sans que quiconque les en soupçonne. L'ouvrage d'Isabelle Nazare-Aga est conçu comme un manuel pratique. La première partie est consacrée aux caractéristiques propres des manipulateurs, ce qui doit permettre de les reconnaître plus facilement. La seconde partie donne quelques pistes pour apprendre à s'en protéger. Hélàs cette deuxième partie, qui aurait pu être la plus intéressante pratiquement, se révèle décevante. Plus courte et moins riche en exemples que la première partie, elle fait figure d'ajout de dernière minute alors que le coeur de l'ouvrage aurait dû se trouver là. Au final, les conseils d'Isabelle Nazare-Aga se bornent à une longue liste de réponses toutes faites à "apprendre par coeur" et censées désamorcer toutes les situations. Le texte n'est pas très bien écrit et, comme c'est souvent le cas dans ce genre d'ouvrages, est émaillé de chiffres et de pourcentages sortis de nulle part et qui ne veulent rien dire, cassant ainsi toute prétention "scientifique".

books.title: Un train pour Tula
books.author: Toscana, David
books.notes: Il est impossible de lire "Un train pour Tula" sans penser aux "Cent ans de solitude" de Marquez: on y retrouve le même réalisme, les personnages rudes et fiers, les hommes fragiles et brutaux, les femmes fortes et terriblement vulnérables, un général d'opérette, un curé meurtrier, un amour implacable qui s'abat sur un enfant et dictera toute sa vie et surtout la ville de Tula, personnage à part entière de cette fresque romanesque.

books.title: Le prédicateur
books.author: Läckberg, Camilla
books.notes: Avec "Le Prédicateur", Camilla Läckberg livre un polar suédois de bonne facture, à mi-chemin entre Henning Mankell et Stieg Larsson: plus fourni et réfléchi que les intrigues du premier, moins noir et complexe que le monde monstrueux dépeint par le second. Même si le dénouement de l'enquête est rapidement prévisible, les moyens pour y arriver le sont moins et maintiennent la tension jusqu'à la la fin, laissant même planer le doute sur certains points. L'intrigue est donc bien construite, même si certains personnages annexes auraient mérité d'être plus développés. Les dialogues sonnent parfois faux et certaines tournures de phrases sont un peu lourdes, les traductrices auraient peut-être dû s'autoriser plus de libertés par-rapport au texte original pour assurer la fluidité du récit?

books.title: Nudge: Improving Decisions About Health, Wealth, and Happiness
books.author: Thaler, Richard H.
books.notes: In this well-structured book, Thaler and Sunstein explore the various ways to present choices to users in a way that will encourage them to wisely use their right to choose. "Choice architecture" seems a very logical concept, yet as the authors are quick to point out, life's complex choices (such as retirement plans) are usually presented in a very discouraging way and more often than not with no sensible "default option". The base idea of the book is interesting, and well illustrated, but in the end it remains a whole book centered around one single idea. And while the proposals to reform medical insurance or retirement plans are very sensible (although very US-centric), the authors also embark in half-baked and exotic ideas, such as the privatization of marriage, that tend to miss the point.[return]People in charge of social security systems should definitely read this book. Other may skim through it to pick up the main idea, which is indeed brillant, but they won't need to read all 300 pages to do so :)

books.title: Pondichéry - Goa
books.author: Pavloff, Franck
books.notes: Dans ce récit, Franck Pavloff entraîne ses lecteurs dans sa recherche vaine et un peu désespérée des dernières traces du passé colonial français et portugais en Inde. Cette quête est abordée avec une naïveté désarmante, qui contraste avec l'évidente culture du romancier: on lui passe volontiers les nombreuses citations de Michaux et les souvenirs un peu répétitifs de son passé de globe-trotter, mais ses maladresses de touriste rendent songeur. Comment peut-on prétendre maîtriser les différences culturelles tout en draguant ouvertement une jeune mère veuve de Pondicherry, en s'étonnant du peu de volonté des Bombayites rencontrés dans le train d'évoquer le terrorisme pakistanais quelques mois après les attentats de décembre 2008, ou en insistant pour parler portugais au gardien d'une guest-house à Goa?

books.title: The Map as Art: Contemporary Artists Explore Cartography
books.author: Harmon, Katharine
books.notes: This superbly illustrated book presens a vast collection of map-related art, exploring the works of well-known as well as obscure artists with the same level of detail. Whether as the intrinsic aesthetic element or as a political statement, maps shown in this book all have a story to tell. At the end, I was nevertheless a bit disappointed, since most art pieces somewhat lack that very special combination of relevant data, precision and pure gorgeousness that sends my map-lover's heart racing...

books.title: Strange Maps: An Atlas of Cartographic Curiosities
books.author: Jacobs, Frank
books.notes: Jacobs' Strange Maps blog is a treasure trove for map lovers, and his book gives his eclectic collection full credit. Imaginary lands, cartographic misconceptions, political maps, parodies, geographic oddities and, well, simply 'strange' maps all find a place here. Discover the world's most intricate enclave system (sporting the only occurrence of a counter-counter-enclave known to man), explore how major religions envision a soul's path through life and beyond, learn why gerrymandering is called like that and shiver through Hitler's world domination maps all between the covers of this atlas of extremes.

books.title: Rats: Observations on the History and Habitat of the City's Most Unwanted Inhabitants
books.author: Sullivan, Robert
books.notes: If you've ever wondered what secret life all those creatures you see scurrying along subway tracks or around the garbage bags of any city in the world, then this book is for you. Even if you're not, actually. Because sure, rats are gross, disgusting animals. But as they are part of the daily life of many city dwellers worldwide, their history is quite close to that of the human being, and their behavior can tell a great deal about ours.[return]Sullivan's book is full of informative facts, funny anecdotes and many forgotten bits of history; a very entertaining read.

books.title: Business Model Generation: A Handbook for Visionaries, Game Changers, and Challengers
books.author: Osterwalder, Alexander
books.notes: This book is full of interesting ideas, mostly coming from creative design, on how to work on a business model, or revise it. Its greatest call to fame: it doesn't look like a business book at all, full of doodles, charts, exercices, concise real-life examples.[return]It only gets 3 stars from me, though, because I really didn't like the badly lit, blurry, camera-phone-like photographs shown in this book. Maybe it's done on purpose to convey "spontaneity", but it contrasts very badly with the otherwise rather aesthetic contents. And, well, despite looking less boring than conventional business books, it is still a book on business models, and business models is still a subject I personally find rather boring...

books.title: The Evolution Of Cooperation
books.author: Axelrod, Robert
books.notes: This book might be a bit dated but it still offers interesting in what makes cooperation between individuals work (or not) by interpreting results coming from a computer experiment in game theory. Axelrod begins by describing the famous "Prisoner's dilemma" and discussing which computer algorithms are the most efficient in solving it. He then shows how many real-life situations can be modeled as "prisoner's dilemma" and how individuals tend to react just as the abstract computer algorithms do. By drawing upon his observations, both in game theory and in real-life examples, the author concludes by giving some tips on how to foster cooperation in a given environment, or how to provide an environment favorable to cooperation. Backed by such simple, rational theory, his advice appear much sounder than most of what can be found in all the business-success-self-help-mumbo-jumbo literature...

books.title: Hinduism : A Very Short Introduction
books.author: Knott, Kim
books.notes: Besides being a rather dated (1998) and poorly illustrated book, this "introduction" to Hinduism is sadly disappointing to the beginner. It fails to address the main subject by spending too much time treating its context. The author does indeed a great job in explaining why defining "Hinduism" itself is a tricky question, and takes alle the necessary precautions to avoid oversimplification and reduce judeo-christian biases. But she goes too far in what should by essence be a "simplification" and leaves the reader clueless about the main facts. On the contrary, prior knowledge of key concepts is regularly implied so that even readers with some basic knowledge about Hinduism will feel frustrated.[return]In definitive, this is rather an "Introduction to how we should discuss Hinduism" as a real introduction to Hinduism per se.

books.title: Minuscules extases
books.author: Grozdanovitch, Denis
books.notes: Un peu vain et d'une affectation à la limite du plausible (le five-o-clock tea accompagné d'un poème chinois tous les soirs sans exception, vraiment?) mais écrit dans un français délicieux. Ce livre ressemble en cela à une boîte de pralinés: c'est évidemment très bon, mais heureusement que la boîte n'est pas trop grande...

books.title: The Forest Unseen: A Year's Watch in Nature
books.author: Haskell, David George

books.title: What's Mine Is Yours: The Rise of Collaborative Consumption
books.author: Botsman, Rachel
books.notes: This is a cleverly written book about what the authors call collaborative consumption, or how the Web 2.0 has finally removed the last hurdles that prevented the humanity from sharing goods and services. The authors dissect the rise of the phenomenon, explain how it came to replace the old "buy more" productivity models, and what made the difference. The result is a convincingly optimistic view of the future, with the emergence of new economic models that promise to be both environmentally sustainable and profitable. What's more, with success stories such as Zipcars, Airbnb or Etsy, collaborative consumption models have proven to bring users together in a fun and satisfying way. Whether you're already a convinced user of these models or looking for new business opportunities, this book is made for you.

books.title: The Mesh: Why the Future of Business Is Sharing
books.author: Gansky, Lisa
books.notes: This book touches a very interesting and important subject (how the internet is now revolutionizing the way we interact with physical objects and services, basically by focussing on sharing ressources as opposed to buying them outright), but sadly fails to keep up with it. There is no real logic to the chapters, as the author mainly seems to be repeating her point over and over while trying to illustrate it with new examples. I bravely read through the whole opus in case I missed something, but I can safely say that reading any 10 random pages of this book will be entirely sufficient, as everything else will be only a slight variation of these pages. Moreover, entire pages are taken over by superfluous "illustrations" that bring no extra information whatsoever. Worse, the illustrations are also plagued by the repetitive curse, further diluting the small amount of extra information they might have added. The author seems nevertheless quite familiar with the concept she exposes, and with several of the examples stated, which is reassuring. Even though she spent her entire professional life in various computer and internet-related companies, she's alas seriously lacking in geek cred, peppering her prose with incorrect technical statements...[return]This book still gets a star for the very good companion website: http://www.meshing.it[return]And half a star for at least trying to bring an important subject to the attention of people who somehow managed to oversee it.[return]If you're interested in this subject, I would instead recommend reading "What's Mine is Yours: the rise of collaborative consumption" by Rachel Botsman and Roo Rogers, who do a much better job at describing the phenomenon and predicting its future.

books.title: The Unwritten, Vol. 1: Tommy Taylor and the Bogus Identity
books.author: Carey, Mike

books.title: In the Woods
books.author: French, Tana
books.notes: Who would have thought that the small woods around quiet Knocknaree in County Dublin, Ireland, would become the scene of two cases of missing children, 20 years apart? In 1984, three local kids disappear into the woods. Only one of them is found, injured and with no memory whatsoever of what happened to his friends. They were never seen again.[return]Two decades later, the found boy, now a detective within the Murder Squad, comes back to the same woods to investigate another gruesome case: the body of a little girl has been found at the very spot where his mates disappeared. Predictably, the investigation soon brings up disturbing memories of his childhood trauma and ends up shattering everything that's been holding him together, including the precious life-long friendship with his partner within the Squad, Cassie.[return]Warning: this multilayered thriller will hold your breath at the end of every chapter and will be hard to put down once started. A true masterpiece of the genre, with a psychological depth rarely found in crime fiction. A must read!

books.title: Her Fearful Symmetry
books.author: Niffenegger, Audrey
books.notes: In a house overlooking the deliciously gothic Highgate Cemetery in London, two young American twins have moved in the appartement of their recently deceased aunt. There, they start a new life of explorations: of the flat itself, London, their own relationship with one another, and some disturbing family secrets. Not to mention the neighboring cemetery, of course... and its sweet, tea-drinking, welcoming guides, one of whom turns out to have been their aunt's lover and is actually living in the same house as them. But why haven't they met him earlier? Why are all windows of the upper flat sealed up? Who will catch the Kitten of Death? Where are Aunt Elspeth's missing diaries? And by the way, is she *really* dead?[return][return]This is a ghost story like you've never read before, it's delightful, original and witty, with exceedingly sympathetic characters. Yet it somewhat lacks the deepness and spark of utter genius that the "Time Traveller's Wife" has, making this a 3.5 star novel only because the comparison with Nyffenegger's masterpiece is hard to match :)

books.title: The Edge of Physics: A Journey to Earth's Extremes to Unlock the Secrets of the Universe
books.author: Ananthaswamy, Anil
books.notes: The Edge of Physics is an excellent foray in the complex field of cosmology, as it explains the various models of the universe through the experiments that aim to prove them right or wrong. By following the author's journey to the inhospitable places where these experiments are being run, the reader gets to understand the beautiful complexity of the questions being tackled, along with their historical backgrounds. Ananthaswamy is a terrific writer, managing to explain very complex theories in easy-to-understand terms, resulting in a popsci book that reads like a thriller![return]There's one big thing missing: pictures. Almost all settings in the book are in fascinating edges of our planet: Antartica, the Andes, Hawaiian volcanoes, the shores of Lake Baikal and so on... and I really missed some pictures to put the experiments in their own context. True, one can always find some on the Internet, but I found myself hugely frustrated by the single black-and-white photo illustrating each chapter.  Mr Anathaswamy, if you need a photographer to illustrate the second edition, take me with you! :-)

books.title: Free: The Future of a Radical Price
books.author: Anderson, Chris
books.notes: In a clear an concise way, Wired editor Chris Anderson efficiently summarizes the various economical models behind Free content and services. The concepts are easy to understand and very well illustrated with relevant real-life examples. Ever wondered how Ryanair manages to sell flights at 0.99£ and yet make money? How come Google Earth is free and yet profits Google even though there is no advertisement? How can a newspaper offer all its content for free online and simultaneously gaining new subscribers for its print version? What is the business model behind Flickr.com? Anderson offers insights in all these questions and more!

books.title: The black swan the impact of the highly improbable
books.author: Taleb, Nassim Nicholas
books.notes: While NNT's postulate is certainly valid and should be wider known (although to a rational mind it sounds rather obvious), diluting it in such a convoluted and rapidly boring book is certainly not giving it credit. Examples are redundant and often contradictory. The author's vast contempt towards economist is satisfying and even amusing at first, but its constant repetition quickly bores the reader. So does the affirmation of Taleb's large ego around every second sentence. A ten-page pamphlet getting to the point would have been much more efficient, but probably less satisfying to the author's reputation and bank account...

books.title: Scott Pilgrim, Vol. 6: Scott Pilgrim's Finest Hour
books.author: O'Malley, Bryan Lee

books.title: Scott Pilgrim, Vol. 3: Scott Pilgrim & the Infinite Sadness
books.author: O'Malley, Bryan Lee

books.title: Scott Pilgrim, Vol 4: Scott Pilgrim Gets It Together
books.author: O'Malley, Bryan Lee

books.title: Scott Pilgrim, Vol 5: Scott Pilgrim vs The Universe
books.author: O'Malley, Bryan Lee

books.title: Scott Pilgrim, Vol. 2: Scott Pilgrim Versus The World
books.author: O'Malley, Bryan Lee

books.title: Scott Pilgrim, Vol. 1: Scott Pilgrim's Precious Little Life
books.author: O'Malley, Bryan Lee

books.title: A Princess of Passyunk
books.author: Bohnhoff, Maya Kaathryn
books.notes: A Princess of Passyunk is a kind of modern-day fairy tale, telling the story of how three princes found their three princesses and lived happily ever after. The three princes take the form of boys of Polish origin living in a Jewish quartier of Philadelphia in what sounds like the 1950s. When his two best friends start drifting out of their baseball games to expore their newly found interest in girls, Ganady sets himself on the quest to find his own "princess". If only his beloved would stop constantly steppping in and out of his dreams, so much that he seriously doubts if she's real...[return]Of course, in a fairy tale everything can happen, so the reader should not be too surprised by girls turned into cockroaches because an evil Baba Yaga had been reading Kafka when she set off her curse, nor by the love stories of supposedly grown-up boys still displaying the naivety of a 12 years old... All in all, the story is mildly amusing and the idea intersting, but somehow it never quite comes together in a satisfying manner. Perhaps there simply are too many things in it: fairy tale, immigration, coming of age, religious and racial tolerance, baseball, baseball and baseball... I had a hard time finishing it.

books.title: And Then There Was No One. Gilbert Adair (Evadne Mount Mystery 3)
books.author: Adair, Gilbert
books.notes: The whodunnit author Gilbert Adair is invited to a literary festival in Meiringen, Switzerland, where Sir Arthur Conan Doyle tried (and failed) to end the life of its hero Sherlock Holmes. When one of the festival invitees is found murdered one morning, investigation is taken over by Evadne Mount, the main character of Adair's own novels come to life. Things get even stranger when the novel itself becomes closely intertwined with the story it is currently describing...[return][return]Peppered with literary references, puns and allusions, Adair's "metafiction" can be a bit hard to swallow for readers less versed in the writer's milieu, but it's definitely an entertaining read. And, as with every good whodunnit, there's a good twist at the end :)

books.title: Fresh Kills
books.author: Nadelson, Reggie
books.notes: A good read but alas definitely not the best of Reggie Nadelson. The usual colorful characters are here, along with the jazzy New York atmosphere, and the base idea of the novel is interesting, but the story somehow fails to bring everything together.

books.title: Cold Fire
books.author: Koontz, Dean
books.notes: Mildly entertaining, but easy to read (and to forget), perfect for a long flight. A bit far-fetched.

books.title: Old Filth
books.author: Gardam, Jane
books.notes: One of the finest stories I've read in a long time! This little jewel is not only a highly entertaining novel, full of dry humor and lovable characters, but also a very interesting foray into the little-known fate of the so-called "Raj orphans". Born to British parents in one of the former colonies of the Empire, then sent "Home" to England at a young age to warrant a proper "british" education, most of these children never or very rarely saw their parents at all, turning them into de facto orphans. Escaping their often loveless childhood, some of them became great men, such as Old Filth, a renowned Hong-Kong barrister. Retired in England, quite alone after the death of his wife, Old Filth suddenly embarks on a journey to the depths of his memory, reuniting with long-forgotten family members and finally coming to terms with his own disturbed youth...[return]Warning: once opened, this book just won't let you go until you've finished it!

books.title: In the Skin of a Lion
books.author: Ondaatje, Michael

books.title: The Inheritance of Loss
books.author: Desai, Kiran
books.notes: The Inheritance of Loss is an interesting novel, set during the insurrection of the Gorkha National Liberation Front in Sikkim (an Indian province between Nepal and Bhutan) in the 1980s. Its originality lies in following the life of various characters, linked by family ties but otherwise living their own personal drama: the Judge, a retired member Indian Civil Service, bitterly recalls his life desperately trying to "modernize" his country after the British had left, his granddaughter Sai watches her world coming apart and her first love being shattered by the insurrection, while the Judge's cook's son Biju discovers that the riches of America are hard to come by for a young illegal immigrant...[return]All in all, it makes for a powerful tale of human miseries, but I personally regret that by intertwining several stories, the author chose not to dive into more details in any one of the characters' life. And it was a bit too depressing for my taste.

books.title: A Perfect Red: Empire, Espionage, and the Quest for the Color of Desire
books.author: Greenfield, Amy Butler

books.title: Au Bon Roman
books.author: Cossé, Laurence
books.notes: Deux fous de littérature décident de fonder la librairie "parfaite", qui n'offre que des romans et refuse catégoriquement les bestsellers convenus et autres succès commerciaux. Dès le premier jour, la petite librairie est prise d'assaut, les amateurs de "bons romans" félicitent les deux courageux entrepreneurs, et promettent de revenir. Cependant, d'étranges évènements viennent bientôt ternir le tableau. Attaques, menaces: quelqu'un en veut à ce havre de qualité. Quelques mois plus tard, un juge d'instruction confie ouvre une enquête peu banale: la victime, c'est la littérature...[return]Laurence Cossé nous offre ici une lecture jouissive, mi-thriller policier mi-roman érudit, un manifeste pour la littérature qui n'y ressemble pas, un conte qui n'est pas sans rappeler Italo Calvino. Et puis au delà de l'intrigue proprement dite, il y a le plaisir de reconnaître les acteurs du monde contemporain de l'édition qui se cachent derrière d'amusants pseudonymes, ainsi que l'agréable dommage collatéral de se retrouver avec une liste d'auteurs à découvrir à la fin du roman...

books.title: The Selected Works of T. S. Spivet: A Novel
books.author: Larsen, Reif
books.notes: Tecumseh Sparrow Spivet is a brilliant cartographer and illustrator living in Divide, Montana, member of 24 learned societies (such as the National Beekeper's Society and the Ronald McDonald Club) and whose work regularly appears in the like of Nature or Science. When he learns that the renowned Smithsonian Museum granted him an award and wants him to deliver a conference in Washington DC, T.S. Spivet readily accepts and starts arranging his trip. Which will not be that straightforward, because he intends to travel without telling his parents: T.S. is only twelve years old.[return][return]This is a wonderful discovery, a very touching story of how a boy earns his place in the world and the respect of his father. While one might forgive the author the slow drift from a rational and plausible story to something closer to a child's tale, the abrupt end of the novel makes it half a star short to being absolutely perfect. But by all means, go and read this. You won't be disappointed.

books.title: Magic for Beginners
books.author: Link, Kelly
books.notes: The best fantasy short stories I've read in a long, long time! Kelly's little marvels are both funny and haunting, lightweight and dark, inspiring and highly enjoyable. And they have it all: aliens! zombies! giant spiders! teenage girls! A drugstore chain explores a brand new customer base in targeting the dead, counselors try to salvage marriages between living and dead through Ouija boards, teenagers find themselves a part of their favorite TV show, a man weds his cannon, a village hides in a handbag, a witch gives birth to her home... each story is a strange and clever universe, bridging the fantastic and the familiar, and sometimes even hides references to other stories: delightful!

books.title: Le Silence de la pluie
books.author: Garcia-Roza, Luiz-Alfredo
books.notes: Un policier rafraichissant, dépaysant et vite lu. Parfait pour la plage :)

books.title: Footnotes in Gaza: A Graphic Novel
books.author: Sacco, Joe
books.notes: A disturbingly powerful document on the endless Palestinian conflict, Footnotes in Gaza takes war journalism to another level. During several months in the Palestinian refugee camps of Rafah and Khan Younis, in the Gaza strip, Joe Sacco tried to shed light on a violent side episode of the 1956 Suez Crisis. This book is not only the story of these tragic events but also the story of the author's struggle to piece together countless eyewitness accounts. Parallels between the situation of the Gaza strip in 1956 and in the present become evident.[return][return]The result is a black and white work of art, a "graphic history" of cinematographic aesthetics and precision.

books.title: Londonstani
books.author: Malkani, Gautam
books.notes: Revise your Hinglish before diving into the everyday life of a "rudeboy" member of a small-time asian gang in west London. Jas, the nerd-turned-tough guy, is desperate to be accepted by the other members of the gang even if it means renouncing a less violent and culturally different nature. Misfits never lasts of course, and as the gang rises and falls we experience how integration backfires for these second-generation immigrants, sticking to values both more modern and ironically more conservative than their parents, detesting everyone who might even look like a "coconut": a person brown in the outside but white in the inside...[return]Once the novelty of the language has sunk in, however, this story lacks a bit in depth and even the quite unexpected twist at the end fails to hide the fact that there is hardly any end to speak of... But said twist clearly makes what's "special" about Londonstani and I rather like the fact that it's hidden so far at the end.

books.title: Melnitz
books.author: Lewinsky, Charles
books.notes: Le lecteur qui décide de suivre l'oncle Melnitz se retrouve plongé dans l'histoire quotidienne d'une famille juive en Suisse orientale, sur quatre générations: de la fin du 19e siècle à la fin de la seconde guerre mondiale. On y découvre les joies et les peines de la famille Meijer dans une région où l'on a trop vite tendance à oublier que l'antisémitisme a sévi comme partout.[return]La traduction en français du texte de Charles Lewinsky est bonne, on y regrette simplement la méconnaissance de la juste traduction en français des noms de lieux et des organes officiels suisses... un problème récurrent dans la littérature suisse-alémanique traduite.

books.title: Fun Home: A Family Tragicomic
books.author: Bechdel, Alison
books.notes: A witty, clever, tender, exquisitely drawn tale of a complex father-daughter relationship, Fun Home is the story of a double coming out. After a long litterary experimentation, the author finally discovers her own homosexuality at about the same time she learns that her father is gay. A few days later, his father having been killed in a car accident, Alison starts reviewing her childhood memories in the light of this new double revelation. Beautiful!

books.title: Asterios Polyp
books.author: Mazzucchelli, David
books.notes: Aesthetic, complex, clever and grappling, Asterios Poylp is a true masterpiece of contemporary graphic novel. Graphic styles specific to the main characters give the author the opportunity to convey much more meaning with each scene: several styles get intertwined as characters meet or part, and evolve with their life... each character "speaks" with its own font, giving them even more personality.

books.title: The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks
books.author: Skloot, Rebecca
books.notes: Through the story of the woman whose cancer cells would eventually become the most widely used cell culture in the history of science, we learn the difficult story of a small Afro-American community through the 20th century, the end of segregation and the surprisingly late birth of ethics in research involving humans.

books.title: Essential Facebook Development: Build Successful Applications for the Facebook Platform
books.author: Maver, John

books.title: Six Suspects
books.author: Swarup, Vikas
books.notes: A nice mystery, exotic and fun, written in the author's trademark fresh and inventive style. The main plot is a bit straightforward (the end twist is hardly a surprise) but the intertwining stories of the main characters are what gives this story all its salt.

books.title: The Department of Mad Scientists: How DARPA Is Remaking Our World, from the Internet to Artificial Limbs
books.author: Belfiore, Michael
books.notes: As a fervent reader of Wired, I'm generally positively impressed by books written by its contributors and so was looking forward to this story of DARPA by Michael Belfiore. But it turned out to be disappointing: military-heavy and without any critical questioning of the technologies discussed or of their planned use: is the US army happily distilling its own jet fuel from vegetable oil in the middle of a battle zone really going to change the world in the way we want it?

books.title: Sea of Poppies
books.author: Ghosh, Amitav
books.notes: Pukka! With "Sea of Poppies", Amitav Ghosh lets his readers embark on an incredible journey through the fascinating era and language of the Raj and the Opium Wars. Through the pages of this dense novels, they will sway over the sea of passions, fate and adventure like the lascar crew of the Ibis over the fearsome Black Waters![return]The Glass Palace was already a masterpiece in historical fiction and if this first episode is anything to go by, the "Ibis" trilogy may well turn out to be the next Lord Jim…

books.title: The Lovely Bones
books.author: Sebold, Alice
books.notes: A wonderfully clever idea to address the difficult matters of child abuse, murder and grief... infused with the right amount of hope and humor.[return]An entertaining and well-written book, but lacking somewhat in depth, becoming less and less interesting with every page towards the end of the story. The last pages seem to have been hastily written to finish off the book... not the ending we would have expected after such a brilliant start.

books.title: Anybody Out There
books.author: Keyes, Marian
books.notes: An Irish girl living the High Life in New York suddenly faces a personal tragedy, to which she slowly tries getting to terms with. Sad and funny at the same time, Anna's story addresses deeper subjects than usual with Marian Keyes novels.

books.title: The Time Traveler's Wife
books.author: Niffenegger, Audrey
books.notes: This is by far one of the strangest, most beautiful love stories I've ever read. The idea of the book is simply brilliant, and Niffenegger exploits every possible psychological implication of time travel, including in situations commonly encountered in "real life".[return]I enjoyed every single line of this book.

books.title: The School of Essential Ingredients
books.author: Bauermeister, Erica
books.notes: You know those delicious pasta you use to cook on a summer evening, delicious even though the recipe is as easy as can be - a couple of ripe tomatoes, basil and olive oil - because all ingredients speak the simple language of a happy summer? Well, this books feels about the same way: easy, fragrant with memories, lovable while light enough to let you think of other things while you're at it. And it's over before you realize it.

books.title: The Name of the Wind
books.author: Rothfuss, Patrick
books.notes: Il est rare d'entendre une légende racontée par le héros lui-même, de comparer ses propres paroles aux bruits qui courent. L'histoire que raconte l'être qui se cache sous les traits d'un aubergiste réunit tous les ingrédients de la 'fantasy' de qualité: un mal mystérieux qui envahit le pays, un dragon, une orgueilleuse Université, un héros incompris, une princesse en détresse et l'amour inaccessible... Quelque part entre Harry Potter et le Seigneur des Anneaux, moins adolescent que le premier et moins accompli que le second, la première partie du récit de Patrick Rothfuss laisse au lecteur le même désir qu'une première gorgée d'eau après une longue route... A quand la suite?

books.title: Fuir
books.author: Toussaint, Jean-Philippe
books.notes: La prose parfaite de Jean-Philippe Toussaint entraine ses lecteurs sur les routes du monde, lui faisant découvrir les recoins oubliés d'une langue magnifique et les contours incertains des relations qu'entretiennent entre eux les humains... "Fuir" est un thriller inachevé, une course poursuite exotique interrompue par un évènement triste et banal, une histoire qui se déguste comme une glace italienne qui fond au soleil: un peu trop vite mais sans regrets pour les gouttes perdues sur les pavés...

books.title: Faire l'amour
books.author: Toussaint, Jean-Philippe
books.notes: Une prose élégante et délicate, un peu vaine, un peu comme un grand vase de fleurs séchées: ça ne sert à rien, personne n'ose le toucher mais tout le monde s'accorde pour dire que c'est très esthétique... C'est un roman à lire tout haut, pour le plaisir de la langue et pour partager ce plaisir. Ce n'est pas un roman à lire le matin dans le métro, où il sera trop vite fini et laissera le petit goût amer du temps perdu...

books.title: Babette's Feast and Other Anecdotes of Destiny
books.author: Dinesen, Isak
